In the morning Winnipeg light, pale and thin as skim milk, Nate Kowalsky rolled the van door shut with a hinge-creak that could be heard halfway down the block. The block was gray and still. Snow didn’t fall so much as just refuse to melt, crudded up into dense berms and glazed spots, the gravel naked in patches where tires had chewed and chewed. He rubbed his gloved hands together, the leather stiff, cords and wire spools bumping his hip through the canvas of his work pants. His breath came out in little comic balloons. If he smiled he could turn them into speech bubbles in his imagination.

“Morning,” he called, more to prove he had a voice than to greet anyone in particular. But there was Mrs. Banerjee across the way, kneeling in her parka, coaxing the world’s bravest little dog over a ridge of tire-packed snow. She lifted a glove, triumphant. The dog lifted a tiny paw and looked offended by the very idea of February.

“You’ll be late,” she said, as if this were a moral failing, the kind that a city would remember. “The roads.”

“That’s what the van is for,” he said. “It’s got opinions about black ice.”

“It has bad opinions,” Mrs. Banerjee said, and the dog sneezed, which seemed like civic confirmation.

He slid into the driver’s seat, swung his Thermos into the cup holder, and exhaled the tightness that work mornings gave him. His chest felt like a cupboard crammed with extension cords. He turned the key and treated the engine to murmured encouragements reserved for old friends and sullen children. It caught. The radio came on to a weather report that might’ve been a joke, except the people on the radio never sounded like they were joking. He turned it down. He wanted to hear the van; it had a way of confiding in him about its health.

The first job of the day was in Wolseley, a century-old house with corners that sagged like surrendered shoulders and baseboards that had seen boot heels, paws, and probably the patience of saints. The homeowner was a young couple with a baby that had a constitution like a French horn. They were converting an attic into a nursery as if proximity to the sky itself were a tonic. He had told them, kindly, that if they didn’t insulate that place like a Thermos bottle they’d be raising a Canadian snowman. They laughed and nodded, and he’d known then that he’d be back in six months to fix what cold air had taught them.

He parked under an elm coarse with frost crystals and hauled his tool bag out by the handles. There was coffee in the bag too—Gertie’s coffee from the Blue Goose Diner—evidence of the detour he’d made, not because he needed caffeine (he did) but because he’d gone for pie. It wasn’t rational, going for pie at 7 a.m., but rationality had never been the boss of cravings. From the Blue Goose he’d emerged with a paper box warm enough to fog his glasses, cradling what Gertie called “breakfast pie,” which was the same as all the other pies but with spunk. Apple and cheddar braided into a crust he’d sworn once he’d heard sing. He told people he ate pie for his health and for economy (calories per dollar, Gertie, I’m doing the math) and sometimes they believed him.

“Come in quick, quick,” called a voice when he knocked at the Wolseley door. He stamped his boots and did not come in quick; years of polite habit rounded off into muscle memory. He stepped into a carpet that felt like it had been poured. The baby honked. The couple looked like people who’d survived a long winter of requests.

“You want me to—” he gestured at the attic hatch, simple and sacrificial.

“If you could just see where the lamp wires go,” the woman said. “They’re acting like a tiny haunted house up there.”

The man added, like a pledge, “We turned everything off in the panel you told us to. Promise.”

Hauntings, in his profession, were either rodents or bad splices. He pulled down the wooden ladder that had the slick of many hands on its rails, and climbed with the calm that came from knowing wood had been trusted by bigger, heavier men than him. The attic smell hit him—dry and sweet, the brittle blueprint smell of old joists and sawdust and the ghost of wool blankets. Light coming through a dormer smeared itself across dust-motes and made even the insulation seem like it might be helpful. He set the lamp down, unscrewed it, and followed the wire as if following a river upstream to its foolish headwaters.

He worked without drama. There is nothing like the rhythm of solving small problems with your hands to keep grandiose thoughts at bay. Strip, twist, cap. Tug, tuck, secure. When the couple came up to see, he explained in simple terms and they nodded like people who were grateful their time was being given back to them.

“It will buzz when the furnace kicks because of the old ductwork,” he told them. “Buzzing is a love language in houses like these.”

He didn’t tell them the things he sometimes thought while he worked, about how inside of every wall was an improvisational theater piece starring nails and temptation. He went back to the van when he was done, scratched a note for his afternoon job in Transcona where the gentleman had a hobby of putting in his own outlets sidewise for reasons that amounted to how “he liked it better.”

At the Blue Goose, earlier, Gertie had looked at him over the pie case like a judge that everyone rooted for despite themselves. Her hair was a snowy cloud arrangeable into no fewer than three landscapes; her wrists were wrapped in bracelets the color of grape jelly.

“You missed the prelims, Nate,” she had said, sliding the paper box toward him ceremoniously. “I would scold you but I don’t scold electrician-hands. Those hands—see? Those hands keep my pastry case lit and the mixer that hates me alive.”

“There was a breaker box older than me with more secrets than me,” he said. “It whispered. I listened. We hugged. It was fine.”

Gertie had a way of asking questions without words. Her eyebrows had a vocabulary.

“You could have been somebody,” she said, theatrically tragic. “You know the Spring Thaw pie-off goes to regionals, and regionals sends one glorious local into the arms of the National Sweet. That’s what they call it now. The National Sweet! Can you imagine?”

“I can imagine sugar,” he had said, because his role at the Blue Goose was sarcasm and awe, colour-coded to Gertie’s approval. Then he’d let it land, what she had said. A second behind his smile, you could always see him thinking. “Wait. I missed the prelims?”

“You did not,” she said, relenting, the eyebrows smoothing into forgiveness. “But I like you better when you leap. It’s this afternoon, three o’clock, down at The Forks. They do it outdoors because they claim fresh air is character-building. As if sugar ever failed to build character.”

He had looked at the calendar on his phone and at the words he had scribbled in his workbook and felt something tug inside his ribs. He told himself it was just hunger switching masks.

He’d always liked watching competitions that made a show out of ordinary pleasures. You didn’t need the aesthetics of athleticism to admire someone standing before an open question: how much, how fast, how joyous? Pie was the opposite of sleek. It slumped. It refused to be a quick story, held together by starch and stubbornness. Gertie made pies that refused to be shamed into neatness. They did not slice well and it felt like a personality trait.

At noon the light brightened in that winter way that only emphasizes how sun here is like cold fire, a flame you are not allowed to get too close to. He hit the job in Transcona as if he were tackling a cousin, and made quick work of reorienting outlets to appease both electrical code and a man’s love of symmetry’s distant cousin, preference. There was something gentle about restoring a thing to code, a tiny social contract, like reminding someone to call their mother. He collected his cheque, paper, folded twice, his name spelled right, a small perfection.

On the drive to The Forks he took his glove off at a long light just to press his fingers against the heating vent. The radio told him a story about a man who had lost a canoe in summer and found it in winter in someone else’s yard. In Winnipeg, carbon-steel notions like ownership had a way of getting buffed by weather into the more interesting concept of neighbor.

At The Forks the river paths looked like poorly kept promises, shinier than you wanted them to be. He followed the signs for the festival, smack into stands selling Ukrainian flags and butter tarts and antler headbands because at some point while he lived ordinarily, someone had decided that antlers were now a noun you could wear for ironic clout. Winnipeg collects irony like an aunt collects teaspoons. You look at the city and think: surely there cannot be more. And then there is.

A crowd had already gathered under the string lights that day refused to overpower. Nate recognized the official in charge—Drew, who was an unofficial battery of every mid-level festival in the city, possessed of clipboard, beard, and a voice that could fling syllables into a crowd.

“Last call for hungry fools,” Drew bellowed, smiling wide. “Get your bibs. Bowl of water to the left, napkins to the right, dignity in a locker somewhere far away.”

Gertie shouted when she saw him, such that strangers parted like a curtain. “He made it,” she declared to no one and everyone. “I am responsible for this.”

“You sure?” Nate said, but he was the one to step into the ring of tables like a man who had just remembered something that mattered to him. He had eaten pie competitively once in high school, in a gym that smelled like varnish and teenage effort. He’d been shirtsleeves and bravery then. Now he was work jacket and longing.

The rules were simple. The pies were Saskatoon berry, blue as the bruises you’d be bragging about later. No hands, forkless, face-first. You had eight minutes to do with your mouth what your hands would do better, and in this there was a lesson.

He found a place at the far end and tied the ridiculous plastic bib around his neck. A woman to his left, short and sharp-eyed, nodded at him like a colleague at a conference. To his right a boy in a toque too large looked both terrified and giddy.

“First time?” Nate asked the boy.

“No,” the boy said, and then turned red. “Yes. I mean, I watch videos online.”

“Videos never smelled like this,” the woman said, and she was right. The air was thick with sugar and fruit and that bakery scent that was equal parts comfort and warning.

When Drew blew the whistle it felt like someone had opened the starting gate on tiny, sweet horses. Nate bent and let himself go. In the first seconds there is always panic—food, in this quantity, is a topographical feature. It isn’t for tasting; it’s for understanding. He understood Gertie’s crust. He found the rhythm, like a man sanding a door in long, even strokes, and listened to his lungs. He knew when to breathe through his nose, shorties and then a long haul, when to let his tongue help, practical and relentless. He felt ridiculous, and then he stopped caring, which is the start of every good performance. He laughed at his own face, which must be a geographer’s dream. For a brief minute, a minute that tasted like berries and regret, he was happy in the way that requires no permission.

He didn’t win. The woman at his left had a technique that made his seem pastoral. She had some secret, possibly to do with how she enforced a mental calorie truce. The boy on his right flamed out quickly and sat back, daubing his cheeks with a napkin like an old man at a sink. Nate finished his pie, finished it entirely, which he set out to do as if closing a loop for a version of himself who wasn’t allowed to waste, ever, as a child. That had been his mother’s voice, the knuckles of it all sincerity and hard work. He lifted his head, laughing, aware of the purple streak he must now carry like a flag.

“Finalist positions will be posted this evening,” Drew announced, after it all, when the contestants stood looking at themselves, the way you do when you’ve done something both silly and sincere. “It’s based on both speed and degree of clean. We are professionals.”

Gertie had edged her way to the table with a stack of napkins anyway. Her bracelets clinked like tiny bells. “You,” she said, meaning him entirely, “were a painting. You were art.”

“I was blueberry slaughter,” he said.

“This is the life you choose,” she said, not unkindly, wiping a dot of juice from his ear as if she were his auntie and not the town’s loudest oracle.

He went home in the dusk, of which there was plenty. Mrs. Banerjee’s dog barked once, like an affidavit, and he waved. In his kitchen, he leaned against the counter and drank water like someone who had been out in the desert and found a public fountain. He took off his boots. The radio, later, said that a person was recommended to do a thing because the heart is better off at rooms where there are stories rather than at doors where there are none.

He checked his phone at 8 p.m., when Drew was likely to have collated the results, armed with a spreadsheet and a beer. His name was, to his surprise, third. Third is such a sweet spot. First is the target; second is okay if you hate bragging; third is an astonishment and therefore pure joy. The top three, the website said in letters that had clearly been decided upon during a committee that believed in excitement by font, would travel to Toronto for the National Sweet.

He read the line twice. The word travel glowed. He had been to Thunder Bay once as a kid, an adventure that had felt like an ocean voyage. He had flown to Vancouver exactly one time for a cousin’s wedding, wearing a suit that had made him feel like a carefully constructed argument. He liked where he lived not because he couldn’t imagine anywhere else but because he could and chose this anyway. But trains. Trains were a story he had told himself many times while driving, the winter’s glittering track insistently parallel to the highway for a stretch out by Transcona, all that metal, those plans. He had always wanted to take the train east like a person who wanted to step into a history that did not include him. Like being allowed to hold somebody else’s heirloom careful: look, don’t break it.

He set the phone down and picked it up again. He texted someone and erased it. He walked around the table the way some people circle new cars, considering. He called his mother.

“Ma,” he said when she answered, the old house in St. Boniface singing its own high note on the line, as if the phone wires remembered voices in the tone of a minor key.

“Nathan,” she said, same as always, the Ukrainian in her voice like embroidery on a plain shirt. “Your Uncle tells me you fixed his shaver.”

“Uncle Brodie fixed his shaver,” he corrected. “I told him not to shave when he’s drowsy. I have news.”

“Please do not tell me you are engaged.”

“Why would that be something you do not wish?”

“Because I would then need to cook what your grandmother cooked, and my hands are not as young as my mouth.”

He laughed. He could see her at the blinds, peeking, the street, her life reduced to a few square panes and a television that tried its best.

“I made a pie eating thing,” he said. “A contest. Do not make the sign of the cross, this is an honest story. I placed. I have to go to the big thing if I can, in Toronto.”

“And you are calling me because I am from Ontario and therefore am responsible for trains,” his mother said, sharp, amused. She had been seventeen when she left her Ontario town for the Prairies, with a suitcase that had been heavy not because of what was in it but because of what she thought she was leaving behind. She still said sorry in a way that made apologies sound like pastries—unexpected, sugar-dusted.

“I’m calling you because I wanted to say it out loud,” he said. “I thought you might say something.”

“I have said many things,” she said. “About hydration, about the sins of sugar. I will say the train from Winnipeg to Toronto is expensive like a fur coat and twice as warm if you choose to sit near the window. Your cousin went that way and did not stop talking about the way Jacques said the word ‘dome’ for days after he met that man from Quebec. People on the train tell you their life because they cannot get off and you cannot get off and in this way intimacy is inflicted. How much is the ticket.”

He clicked and tapped. The website for Via Rail did that polite thing of pretending it had lots of options and then slowly declining most of them. He read the categories aloud. Economy. Upper. Sleeper. His mother hummed at the dollar amounts like a person unsure whether to take thirds.

“It’s a lot,” he said finally. “And this is assuming I go without a bed and just…arrange my body. Which it does not love.”

“Ah,” she said. “The world charges for dreams like it charges for novelty t-shirts. For the printing and for the idea. You have money.”

“I have enough money for my new tires and for uncle’s shaver and for a couch that doesn’t slump in the middle, not theatrical dreams,” he said. He said it lightly but he knew the numbers. He had a mind like a tidy junk drawer where, if you moved the elastic bands and twist-ties, there were facts too.

“Maybe they pay you,” she said.

“They pay you in applause and a commemorative bib.”

“A family heirloom,” she said, and he heard her smile. “I will pray—it’s what I do—for a sponsor. The world is full of people who love to give their name to other people’s pie. And if not, then you will go another time. You will be sad, and then you will not be sad, and you will be happy in a way that isn’t about the going.”

She was like that. She had a way of pulling the thread of a thing until the knot said fine, fine, you’re right. He didn’t want to skip the sadness, though. He wanted to stand in both the wanting and the reality like a person who can hold two plates without dropping either and also acknowledge that he is not a juggler. He told her he loved her. She told him to wear his hat in that wind that came across the field like a rumor that had turned into a fist.

After he hung up he sat silently. The fridge hummed. Somewhere below him someone sneezed; the building echoed it back politely. He had no spare money lodged anywhere obvious. Work had been steady but not extravagant, his habit of putting cash aside consistent and not miraculous. He had never learned the magic some people knew: summoning big money at a moment’s notice. Bingo luck. Uncle money, lottery, mysterious envelope. The only thing he knew how to do was more of what he already did, and time was a pie you couldn’t cut more of.

He came awake the next morning planning to not think about it, then thinking about it anyway, because the mind is a dog let out into the yard and it always goes to the same spot first. He had a job in a café off Corydon where the owner wanted more black track lighting even though the ceiling was low enough to gossip with. He hauled the ladder in, nodded to the barista who looked like a photograph of a barista, and made a world of small black fixtures align like planets in a tiny galaxy. People sat under the future lights and ate scones, and their hair caught even the minimal morning light like it was a secret they’d been hoping to keep. He thought about asking the café woman if she would sponsor a sweet-toothed electrician and get her name on a bib. He did not ask. There is a fine line between audacity and theft, and he did not yet have the boots for it.

At lunch he parked by the river and climbed onto the little footbridge to watch the brown water move under its shell of ice. Winnipeg has two rivers and they move like a dispute, slowly, in public. The breeze cut his eyes. A skate-bladed couple glided past holding hands like a metaphor that refused to stay where it belonged. He took a picture of the sky because it was one of those days when it looked like it had been ironed by someone conscientious. He sent the picture to his friend Raj with the caption: people are moving on purpose.

Raj sent back a series of dumpling emojis and then: drew told me u’re in. what’s the plan.

He typed: i halved the plan with the universe and it kept the half with the dollars. he added a shrug, and then felt childish, and then sent it anyway.

There was work to do: a panel to upgrade in a new-old house in St. James where a guy named Brad who had really wanted to be named Bradley insisted that the panel be flush with the wall because he hated “bumpy things.” Nate said it could be done but would be ugly; Brad hesitated at the ugly, and then made the right call, the good choice that men who want to be named something else often have hidden inside them. Nate unspooled cable like a fisherman and felt the tautness in his shoulders that sometimes made him think he was a part of the structure he was working on. He was in it; he might as well be in it.

Every spare moment, in the van, in line at the hardware store where he knew the price of outlets and the names of the people who bought them in bulk, he did math. Train fare. Food. A cheap place to sleep. He opened tabs that he then shut because looking at them hurt. The festival was a week away. There were emails now from the organizers with words like “delighted” in them, words that were, against all logic, persuasive. There were small print details. He read them like a good boy. No assistance. No outside sponsorship unless approved. Waiver. The word waiver is never used for anything you would truly want to do; it’s involved when someone somewhere thinks there’s going to be fun and therefore probably risk. There was a line about “travel is the responsibility of the contestant.” He marked it yellow, for emphasis he didn’t need.

At the Blue Goose that week, Gertie made special pie with a heart cut in the top. She offered him a slice for free and he paid anyway. He told her about the trains.

“Ah, the train,” she said. “I once took a train to Montreal and we shared a table with a man who had never learned to say the word ‘oats’ without sounding like he was confessing something. I had a bunk. I pretended that my bunk was a private cabin and my cabin was a small country. Every women deserves a tiny country.”

“I’d take a seat,” he said. “I’d make it a country anyway.”

She considered. “Do you have a girl,” she said, and he laughed at how sudden she was.

“I have a mother and a van,” he said, “and a neighbor who scolds. Does that count.”

“You have hands that can hold a wire without fear,” she said. “You will not always be alone.” It wasn’t pity; it was prophecy, fixed with a fork.

“I don’t fear wire,” he said. “I fear invoices.”

It took three more days for it to land in a way that felt like truth—the no of the train. There wasn’t a dramatic moment, no last-minute phone call, no denial of a loan or a cruel card decline at a gas pump. There was simply, on a Thursday evening, a mirror and his face in it, and he said out loud, “I’ll not go,” and the face didn’t flinch. He felt the no settle into the kitchen like a guest who understands how to keep his elbows in. He wrote the email to Drew, the man of clipboards, and chose words that weren’t a scream even though his chest wanted one. He said: I’m unable to make it to Toronto. Select someone who can. Congratulations to the others.

The send button was a small red thing. He pressed it as if he were a man turning off a light in an empty room. Then he went out, because the house seemed intent on telling him things he did not want to hear too loudly. He walked and let his boots mind their own business on the packed and glittering ruts. A kid down the block had built a snow fort and made a sign for it in marker on a pizza box. It read: no dogs and no adults who hate forts. He wanted to stand at the entrance and recite his credentials. He qualified, technically.

He found himself at The Forks again, in that way that you do when your feet know places they want to wander when your mind is busy. It was later, near close, the vendors beginning their slow and practiced rituals of tidying away. He walked past the ice sculptures where angles had been made to pretend they were delicate not for long. He sat on a bench and felt the cold come through it and into his bones, where he could breathe it out slowly. He might have stayed there until his anger turned into something else. Or he might have stood up and smashed the pie-stand cardboard cutout of a smiling berry with his boot. He did neither. He looked at his phone for no reason and then remembered that his hands were cold and put it away.

“Hey.” It was a voice that had always felt like a tap on the shoulder—a little too much familiarity for the first moment. It was Raj, who had a way of being anywhere that felt like both a trick and a kindness.

“I told you I would regret it,” Raj said, sitting beside him, using the plural you of best friends. “But I also told you I would not try to change your mind. Possibly I lied about that second part.”

“I cannot be the guy who crowdfunds pie,” Nate said. “I mean. That sentence? That is a sentence that cannot be lived down in a city of this size.”

“You don’t need to crowdfund,” Raj said. “You need a patron. Sponsors. Someone who makes flour. Someone who makes forks.” His mind was a market. He pressed his gloved hands to his knees and bounced his heels and then stopped, aware of the reading now in Nate’s posture—no bouncing.

“Gertie,” Raj said, because solutions have to be at least proposed. “She loves you.”

“She loves dramatic speeches,” Nate said. “I am a man made of minor chords.”

“Then a minor-chord man lets his friends set banners behind him while he continues to play minor chords until someone cries,” Raj said. “I know, yes, pride. I am messy. You are tidy. Let me make a case.”

“You say that like we don’t become who we are because of the kitchens we grew in,” Nate said. “My mother taught me to take instead a smaller piece and to be grateful. Your mother taught you to reach bravely and apologize later with cookies.”

“The cookies were excellent,” Raj said. “They solved crimes. They solved wars. Eat one and forgive me for wanting you to go to the thing you want to go to.”

Nate breathed. It steamed. He thought about how the city looks from the train window: the yards and siding, the backs of houses, the undershirts of neighborhoods. He thought about how his life, small and neatly arrayed like a toolbox he liked to open and look at sometimes just to feel he was the kind of person who liked order, might make room for something sloppy.

“Okay,” he said, and his own okay startled him. But he’d only said okay to listening.

Raj didn’t crow. He relaxed his shoulders. “There are ways,” he said. “There are rooms with people who want to put their big names on small brave things.”

He did not say: my uncle knows a guy, because this was not that kind of favor. Instead he took out his phone and showed Nate a message he’d already written to their friend Flor in communications with the community arts council. It was beautifully worded, a way to ask without it sounding like begging. It was not an ask, even, so much as an offering: a chance to be associated with a good story. Nate read it and something in him did not object.

The next day he went back to work in a small office in an old bank building, the vault now a copy room, the thrill of walking inside of it still new enough to be the good kind of childish. He cut conduit to length. He measured twice. Measured again. He let the day keep him honest. His phone buzzed late afternoon with a message from Drew anyway: sorry to hear it. if anything changes, the spot is yours.

He typed and erased three responses. He finally sent: thanks. if something changes you’ll be the first to know besides my mother.

He went to the Blue Goose afterward without knowing he was going there until he was there, his boots already at the mat. Gertie pointed at him with a knife, then realized what she was doing, and made it into theater, which is to say she flourished. “Hero,” she said, like a threat. He could see she’d heard.

“It’s not a tragedy,” he said quickly. He didn’t want to see it reflected back at him that way. He had a dislike of melodrama unless it was clearly labeled. “It’s an ordinary no.”

She reached for a paper plate, set it on the counter. She did not put pie on it because she was not an insult comic. “Some ordinary nos hold up the world,” she said. “When you are ninety-eight you’ll speak with fondness of the day you didn’t go to Toronto because of stubbornness and money.”

He didn’t know whether she was gently scolding or gently teasing so he gave her the sincerity he had. “I wanted to go,” he said. “So I wanted to say it. Out loud. To someone who’d hold it steady and not turn it into a lesson or sad song. To just say it, and let it be real and not be the end of anything.”

“There is a pie for that,” she said. “I put thyme and lemon in it for people who insist on complicated feelings.”

He smiled. “You making that up.”

“It’s in the back,” she said, and then went to the back because sometimes a person tells you where they’re going because the idea of surprise is not kind.

He sat on the stool at the end of the counter where he had sat many times and looked out at his city through the glass, where the shapes of people in coats are mostly identical and the only way you know someone is by how they move. Winnipeg had a way of making you small and then rewarding your faithfulness if you stayed small. He loved it. He resented it a little. He loved it again. When Gertie came back with pie that smelled like a garden had agreed to have tea, he felt the little sigh his heart made when a thing was right.

“Eat your complicated feelings,” she said. “Then come to the back because a man from the Winnipeg Agricultural Society is paying me for pie and this may be a coincidence or an omen.”

He forked thyme and understood, in that moment, that happy was not a place he would arrive at with flags. It was something to be located inside a day like this: heavy boots, a ladder, a laugh at the right time, a no that you can say and survive, a pie with thyme in it just because someone thought you might need to chew on the idea.

The man from the society wore a suit of the sort that makes a person look as if he has somewhere else to be and the decency to pretend he does not. He had a grin like a row of dominoes, straight, ready to run. He loved Gertie because all the sensible people did.

“I heard about your boy,” he said to her, indicating Nate with a skim of his chin. “Not all our heroes are hockey.”

“True,” Gertie said. “Some of us are pastry.”

The man grinned. “We have some community funds for travel for silly reasons,” he said. “Look, I will not pretend we’re building a hospital. But we fund the quilt-makers and the square dancers and the man who makes tiny ships in bottles and then breaks the bottles on purpose in a performance art thing I frankly do not understand. We make room for joy. We’d like to help him go to Toronto. I called the council. They told me they’d already heard from a Raj. We all apparently want to be part of this.”

The thrill that rose in Nate had to be tamed; he had practice. He folded his hands, imagined he was talking to wire. He said the thing he believed he should. He said, “I don’t want—” and then paused, because he could hear what he was about to do to his own luck, the thing pride sometimes does that is just self-sabotage with polish. “I don’t want to be obliged,” he said instead, truth but not ruinous. “I would want to be wearing the name of the thing that helps me and not making a fuss about it.”

“You’ll let us put a wheat sheaf on your bib,” the man said, like an oath, and stuck out his hand and then pulled it back because nobody shakes hands anymore and also his hand was sticky. He wiped it on a napkin and then extended it again. Real handshake this time, warm palm, sincere grip.

Nate laughed, too loudly in his own hearing, the way you do when something relieves tension you were pretending you did not have. He looked at Gertie, who nodded at him like a general. He took the man’s hand and a little bit of what he had wanted settled into him, quick and lovely as a spoon. He said, “Okay. Okay.”

The man wrote a number on a piece of paper, a pledge like a neighborly handshake written down. It was not a number that solved everything, but it didn’t have to be; it made the rest possible. He had some saved. He could do the rest. It meant, practically, a week of careful dinners, a fraying of comfort in the service of purpose. He understood that trade. He took the paper and folded it and imagined the train.

That night he lay in bed and let the train in his head go east. Past the yards. Past the backyard trampolines and laundry lines. Past the flat line of fields carved into snow and then through forest, true wild, where the sky lowers itself as if to eavesdrop. He could feel the motion of it. He whispered to himself like a man calming something. He said, so quiet, “I get to go,” and believed it.

In the morning, he went to the Via Rail site again and this time he did not close the tab. He found a fare that did not break him, and a seat that promised a window. He put in his card numbers the way he always did, resolute as screws. He clicked purchase and the little wheel spun and for a second the universe could have gone either way, because that is how computers perform suspense, and then it slowed, and stopped, and he had a ticket number.

He set the phone down and stared at the ceiling as if it were painted with a map only he could read. It felt—of course it did—like the opening of something large, even though he knew it might be only the opening of a very small thing that looked large today. It was good. Even if he did not win a thing besides a bib and his own giggle, it was good.

He went to work. It was easier to carry ladders when your heart is full. He pulled wires and fixed switches and in one living room talked softly to a timid cat who believed the ladder was an insult. Winnipeg did its Winnipeg thing and served him a day in a tone between steel and caramel. He ate soup out of a thermos because being careful doesn’t have to taste like punishing yourself. He skipped the Blue Goose because he didn’t want to make the day too neat. He saved it for tomorrow. He saved—the habit of this was a muscle. It made other kinds of saving feel possible.

On the last night before he left he went to his mother’s to drop off a spare key because she liked to check his plants and eat his yogurt and pretend she was only checking whether his stove was on. She made him borscht as if he were leaving for sea and could never find beets again. He told her the plan and she nodded as if trains were old friends she had always expected to see reappear at this very moment, on her doorstep, with pie.

“When you look out the window,” she said, wiping her hands on a dish towel that had been a better dish towel long ago, “you will think you are seeing a movie. Twice you will see a moose and think you imagined it. Once you will see a fox. You will pass through the dark and wake in the dark and your body will say what is this. You will listen to someone tell you the whole of their life and you will be a good man and not be bored. You will be smaller when you get there because you left yourself behind, part of you, and it will catch up.”

He smiled. “You’ve done this.”

“I have stayed awake at night while waiting for trains to arrive that were late and told myself stories about people on them,” she said. “It is the same.”

He hugged her. She smelled like onions and winter. She put two pairs of socks in his bag as if the modern world had forgotten to invent warm socks and mothers were still required. He let her. He would wear them and when his feet were warm he would think: I am a person with a mother.

When he left, she stood at the window doing the thing that she always did, which was to pretend she wasn’t thinking about saying something that she then said. She lifted the pane and leaned out a little, as if speaking to a child at a snowbank. “Nathan,” she said. “If you win, you will forget at once the train ride. If you do not, you will remember. Either way, call me.”

“I will call you,” he said, out loud, to the winter, to the person he had been when he had said no, to the person he was becoming now in the chill that said: pay attention. He put his hands in his pockets and walked along the shoveled sidewalk, grateful to the unknown neighbor who had done that good and beautiful thing before the city had to ask. The moon was out, scissored by bare branches. He thought: a life is like this, sharp, pale, sometimes needing to borrow light. He thought about pie and about trains and about wire and about hands that could hold all of it, gently, without dropping, for as long as necessary and then longer. He went home to sleep the way a well-wound clock must sleep—by permission.He woke before his alarm and lay there in the innocent dark of a winter morning, his body aware of the appointment before his mind could line up its reasons. The radiator ticked like a polite insect. Somewhere in the building’s lungs, water made a sound like it had to be somewhere else in a hurry. He reached for the phone and did the thing he had decided he would do last night when he had imagined, with the righteousness of a man about to be tested, that he would act like someone who didn’t need reminding: he turned the alarm off before it could boss him. He made coffee with the same neatness he brought to panels, set out his Thermos, set out the two ham-and-mustard sandwiches he had wrapped in wax paper because foil felt like theater for a man on a train. He checked his bag in a sequence—socks (mother: accounted for), ticket on the phone, spare portable charger, a sweater that felt like a hug with an opinion, two paperbacks because as much as he trusted modern batteries he trusted pages more. He put a small screwdriver in the outside pocket because you never know when you might be required to show the world that hinge pins and battery compartments have nothing to fear.

He stepped into the hall with the reverence reserved for a quiet that could be injured. The stairwell air had that institutional tang of floor cleaner and old snow. Outside, the curb looked like it had grown up with him, familiar and unbothered by his news. The van was a dark shape under a fine glaze, everyone’s sugar, the street’s confirmation. He scraped the windshield with the brisk efficiency of a man with a train to catch and a dislike of performative struggle. He didn’t trust the van to be forgiving if he left it in long-term parking, and besides, Raj had already texted that he would drive him the last few blocks from his place because he liked the idea of being part of the procession of departure. He slid behind the wheel and listened to the engine’s mile-long yawn and thought, not self-mockingly, that the sound of you leaving is sometimes the first applause.

Union Station in Winnipeg has the kind of bones that make you behave. Its stone makes you feel like you would be a better person if you lowered your voice. The long hall held a handful of figures—people who knew the train schedule in their legs, people who had never taken a train before and were thinking very hard about how to make that obvious, people who had done this enough to look bored and were in danger of being mistaken for romantic. The bench seats had polished a shine into themselves with decades of waiting. Above it all, the ceiling looked like something that had once been painted with angels and then, in a fit of prairie pragmatism, sanded down to a dignified cream.

He stood with his bag at his feet and looked at the departure board because you have to look at something. PORTE 1 clung to the French like a refrain. TORONTO VIA THE LAKEHEAD looked like a story you could add pictures to. The announcement came in the two voices of the country, the second voice with the roundness his mother teased into the word sorry, and he found himself relaxing as if the bilingualism were a blanket. The track listing clicked a column over. A child somewhere dropped a toy and howled as if offended by gravity itself. A man with a guitar case had the broken proud look of someone who had decided a long time ago to keep doing a thing that loved him only most days. On the wall, the framed photographs of trains through seasons were arranged with the moral weight of saints.

Raj appeared out of the winter like it was a curtain he was parting for effect. He had a paper bag that had the exaggerated grease blush of breakfast sandwiches too eager to be coy. “One is for me,” he said, already chewing, “and one is for you unless you have decided to live like a monk on this sacred morning.”

“I have ham,” Nate said, lifting the corner of his bag as if to show documents. “But I will not argue with egg.”

“You should never argue with egg,” Raj said, and put the bag into his hand and then did what good friends do when their jokes land in rooms that are serious: he stopped. He looked at Nate and said, low, not for drama but to get it into the ear in the true way, “I am proud. I would be proud if you were going to a conference about screws. But I am especially proud because this is the kind of thing people will call silly and you did not let that word decide for you. Take pictures from the window. If you see a moose, I will accept a description that is mostly antlers.”

Nate grinned in spite of the part of him that was busy recounting the order of cars in a train he could not see yet, like reciting a prayer to calm a stomach. “I will text you if I see a fox,” he said. “The moose can be saved for a poem.”

They bumped shoulders because hugging felt like showing off in a building that had seen troops leave for wars and children leave for colleges and didn’t need his little sentimentalities performed in the aisle. When they called boarding, he moved with the group down the long throat of the platform toward the snow-breathed beast that was the Canadian, its stainless sides dull in the pale light, windows winking like patient eyes. The conductor at the stairs had the kind face of a man who had been asked many questions about assigned seats and was still willing to answer them as if for the first time. “Coach to the right,” he said, in a rhythm that was geography and refrain. “Dome open later. Lake on your left if you’re lucky.”

He found his seat with the instinct of someone who has learned the algebra of personal space: not too near the bathroom, not under a vent that had opinions, not next to the man with shoes shedding mud like a confession. He slid his bag up and felt the relief of closeness and containment that envelopes sometimes give. Outside, the platform looked like a stage you had walked away from while the show continued behind you. A woman tapped on his window and he startled until he realized she hadn’t tapped; his own brain had delivered an echo of every farewell movie ever made, the hand on glass, the train pulling away, someone running and someone no longer running.

The train’s first lurch had the weight of decision. It carried them past the brick and stone of the station, past the winter-still Forks and the stutter of people on blades on the Red River skating trail, past the wefts of graffitied retaining walls where spray paint had turned teenage desire into geography, past yards with trampolines like winter crowns, past piles of snow like moats around small castles of practicality. Winnipeg spread its paleness beside them and then, without ceremony, dropped away into flat. He watched the city go with an attention he reserved for goodbyes he didn’t intend to make a fuss over. He was not leaving for good; he would be home before his philodendron had time to register his absence. Still, the sensation was clear: there he went.

In the seat beside him an older woman unrolled a little wool blanket that had clearly been to more places than some people. She had the calm of a person who carried knitting without needing to take it out yet. On the aisle, a boy with a buzz cut scrolled on a phone and chewed gum with the passionate energy of someone who had not had coffee and yet possessed a metabolism like a series of trampolines. Across the way a man in a parka with reflective strips sat down and promptly fell asleep, his hands folded under his chin as if in prayer. The car had that sound trains have, a layered set of songs: the whir and clack, the occasional thunk of track realities, a soft hiss when the car sighed at a crossing as if exasperated with the way humans arrange roads with such confidence.

He took his sandwich out and ate it in polite bites because something about trains made you perform your manners for the floor. The mustard was perfect. He let his eyes be greedy. The prairie in winter can be accused of sameness by those who only look at the big shapes. He had learned differently. There were lines, tucked under lines, history lain down by wind and by hand, fences that stood anyway, crows like punctuation. The sun worked hard and advanced the light only a little, stubborn as a mason setting bricks in cold.

By Portage la Prairie a child had made her way past with a plastic horse whose mane had known the indignities of love. She fell into Nate’s aisle with the abandon of people who consider gravity only an occasional suggestion. The horse’s tail detached in protest. The child’s face did that morphing thing all kids’ faces do—astonishment into betrayal into fury—about a plastic tail. He was already bending with a hand out, because the reflex to hand a screwdriver to grief was deeply ingrained. He took the little tail in his palm, turned it, saw the tiny nub of a post that needed a patient twist, and reached into the pocket that had the tool he had packed precisely for this sort of thing he hadn’t been able to name. He looked at the mother—young, tired, eyes like someone who had read the night from start to finish without blinking—and lifted his eyebrows with the question. She nodded, gratitude already queued up behind her reserves.

“It was born without it,” the child announced, already having decided the narrative.

“All the best horses improvise,” he said, and turned the post, gentle, slow, a half-spin and in. The tail sat back in the place designed for it as if this had always been a moment trees had been grown to become. He handed it back solemnly. The child took it with the seriousness kids reserve for people who don’t tell them they’re cute. “Thank you,” she said, as if reporting to a captain. She turned to go, remembered something, and returned to show him that the horse could indeed swish, a demonstration so proud and so brief it elevated the whole day by a centimeter.

By the time they reached the turn where the tracks begin their long conversation with lake and forest, people had established the habits that would carry them for the next many hours. The man with the reflective jacket snored politely. The boy with the gum had acquired a deck of cards and, lacking a partner, dealt solitaire in a way that made it look like he was practicing for a life of spectacular disagreements with fate. The blanket woman brought out her knitting and knit as if there were a level of peace available to those who counted stitches. A conductor came through with the check, the punch on the paper tickets making a snow of tiny circles on the carpet where they had been made a hundred thousand times before. He wore a name tag that read JACQUES in neat black letters, no extravagance, and the way he said dome to the woman across the aisle had that roundness his mother had mentioned, the vowel a longer joy than his tongue would have given it.

“You can go up into the dome whenever you like,” Jacques said, finding the line between instruction and invitation. “It is better when it is darker. You see everything and nothing and it is romantic if you are in the mood and spooky if you are not.”

“I am exactly in between,” the woman said, and Jacques smiled in a way that said he had been in between and had lived to tell it.

When Nate wandered forward later, the car with the curve of glass felt like entering a throat made of sky. The seats pointed upward and outward, an insistence, a gentle bossiness to look, really look. The winter was a flicker book. Trees pressed up to the tracks like those kids at aquariums who cannot help but stick their tongues to the glass to see if the ocean will taste of anything besides cleaner. Once, twice, three times, he thought he saw a fox unspool itself from shadow and race parallel a few yards before cutting away into certainty. People murmur in dome cars. It has the feeling of a church, of a place designed for awe where even the atheists keep their voices low because it seems rude to speak at full human volume in front of trees that have agreed to be beautiful for us even when we are busy.

He watched as low roofs of small towns slid past, the names on their water towers like nicknames you could make poems out of if you were that kind. He saw a snowmobile trail intersect the world like a private thought. He felt the train’s power—the part that isn’t noise but a muscle working somewhere below your feet, a kind of giant calf raising and lowering itself in smooth mechanical repetitions—and thought about how none of this happened because of magic and all of it looked like magic anyway. After a while, Jacques came up and sat on the little step at the top, the way conductors have a right to occupy any liminal space, and told a story to no one in particular because dome cars make storytellers generous.

“I was a boy when I first rode this and I got a nosebleed,” he said, addressing the glass as if it owed him a response. “My mother did not have a tissue so she used the ticket. It looked like the trip itself had cost blood. When we got to Thunder Bay she cried in a way she did not think I could hear, and I thought, ah, the world is too big for my mother. Then she tied a scarf around her head and went into the station and came out holding a paper bag and she had bought doughnuts and I thought, no, my mother is too big for the world.”

Nate listened and smiled into his sleeve because the story was entire and didn’t need him to poke it. He let the day lay itself down. He went back to his seat when his stomach told him about time. He ate half of one ham-and-mustard sandwich and saved the rest because he averaged abundance as a policy. He texted his mother a picture of nothing in particular—white and trees and the edge of train window—and she texted back: drink water, and then, because she was a person who could not resist transformation, she added: and look for fox. He texted Raj a moose emoji followed by a question mark. He texted Gertie a picture of the dome with the caption: where angels and old men with stories live, and she sent him back seventeen wheat-sheaf emojis and a sound file of her saying in a stage whisper: do not disgrace Manitoba.

Everything took longer than you think on trains because you have to wait for other versions of your plan to finish doing theirs on the rails. The freight hung around on sidings, enormous patience disguised as unwieldiness, and they stopped to let the work of the country pass them the way you hold a door for someone carrying something that might break your foot. Nobody in the car seemed especially upset by the delays because everything about the train asks you to consider that perhaps time hunger is a habit and not a requirement. If he felt a small bite of anxiety at the thought of arriving late into a city that would not wait for him to put his heart down and find the door he needed to find, he did not let it goad him. He looked at the schedule and at the printed sheet they had given him at the station and he did the math the way he did math for panels, with an acceptance that sometimes numbers can be persuaded by tone.

At a longer stop, somewhere that smelled like tin and frost, the smokers lined up under a sky that did not care about nicotine or sorrow. He stepped onto the platform because his bones wanted novelty. Cold ran up his pants like a prankster and then he was fine. The air had that bite that makes you stand straighter without permission. He had a thermos and cradled it in his hands and sipped in the church of outdoors because coffee has souls in it when you are facing a line of trees that you will never, ever be able to name. A woman beside him lifted her face to the blue as if she had an argument with it. “My nephew lives in Owen Sound,” she said, apropos of the sky. “He says people in Toronto do not know how to drive, and I tell him: people anywhere forget their hands when the streets are large.”

“Hands are everything,” he said, because he was an electrician and the statement needed no qualification.

She nodded. “You look like a man who fixes small things as if they were big,” she said. “We are grateful for you, even if we’re not in your house when you’re doing it.”

Back in his seat, he found he had become enough of a person in the car for someone to slide a crossword toward him with the nib of a pen pointed at 18 down. “Conductor’s call,” the boy with the cards said, excited to share puzzle as if it were a contraband candy. “Six letters.”

“Tickets,” someone said from two rows back, and the boy glowed as if he had been offered a job. They filled in words together for a few minutes and it felt like the sort of community that can only exist between strangers, a temporary country with no taxes and polite customs.

When the light tilted down toward evening, domes collected people again. The car drew out of it the people who did not yet know what it was they wanted and then gave it to them, the trees in that end-of-day color that looks like the inside of a ripe pear. Snowmelt in ditches crusted over in sudden cold looked like glass put down by someone who had intended to come back to it with a sketchbook. The rhythm altered, the train negotiating a section of track that had opinions, and a small girl said wow at exactly the moment you would want a small girl to say wow and everyone let out the breath they didn’t know they were holding because it is kind when someone does the feeling-labor for you out loud.

He slept in the hunched, undignified posture of economy class, his neck making a list of complaints and then agreeing to deliver them later to his pillow rather than now to the car. He woke at odd hours and the outside was another country each time, night having made arenas of the spaces between trees. He went to the snack car at two in the morning because he wanted to test the theory that all coffee tastes better when bought at an hour that makes your future self frown, and found it wrapped in a glow that made everyone look like actors on a set where the set dresser had been paid for their good taste. He bought a coffee that was mostly generosity and a cookie that had a surprising integrity, and he took both to a seat by the window and looked at his own reflection as if he were a man he had not met yet. A couple in their sixties argued softly about the route of a road they had driven thirty years ago. A young guy with a tattoo of a swallow on his neck gazed at his phone with the tenderness of a parent at a sleeping child. The attendant ran a rag along the counter with that eternal rhythm of people who tend small, necessary surfaces.

There was a flicker at the far end of the car, the overhead lights doing the indecisive blink that heralds either a bulb in its last act or a switch complaining about age. The attendant’s face did the quick math of potential annoyance. It was impulsive, or maybe it was the sort of impulse that has been trained to think of itself as duty, but Nate lifted a palm like a student and said, “Do you mind if I take a look.” He said it softly so as not to call himself what he didn’t want to be called, a savior for something that didn’t require one.

The attendant looked at him and then at his hands and then at the small screwdriver peeking from his pocket because there are tells to competency. “If you can sweet-talk that fixture into giving me another two days, I’ll buy your coffee,” she said, and he smiled because the coffee was already drunk but the deal was good in spirit and that’s what mattered.

He climbed up on the little bench, careful, deliberate, holding himself lightly as if his body could be made shame-proof by grace. He popped the lens cover with a practiced wrist and set it on the counter like a delicate object even though it was plastic that could take a joke. He checked the connections, snugged the wire in the tiny clip that had clearly been jostled by time and the particular jiggle of trains, and saw the flicker settle out to a calm he could feel as much as see. He replaced the cover, wiped his palm on his jeans in that universal gesture of done, and stepped down to a small chorus of ah, which is the sound humans make when the world remembers itself. The attendant slid him a napkin with a scribble on it and he laughed when he read it later. The napkin said: one free cookie redeemable upon proof of sorrow. “You look like you’ll have one worth a cookie at some point,” she said, and he waved the napkin like a white flag, like an agreement, like permission.

The hours between dusk and perfect night passed in murmurs. He slept a little more and dreamt nothing he could retrieve. At dawn he was awake before the light and then in it when it arrived, the forest becoming more itself. Northern Ontario unrolled in patient squares and circles of stubborn growth. Rock shouldered up out of the earth as if to say: I remember glaciers and you do not. Lakes appeared and left with a shyness that made you wish to apologize as you looked at them. Occasionally a moose-shaped dark would be insisted upon by someone and then apologized for when it turned into a bush with too much confidence. He saw a fox. He saw it with the uncomplicated joy of someone whose mother had made a prediction that the universe had decided to honor. It moved across a clearing with a pace that had nothing to do with human time. He lifted his phone for the picture and then did not, because he wanted to have something that was only for him and his mother and anyone he loved enough to tell.

His mother answered on the second ring when he called from a little vestibule that smelled like coin and cold and the kind of oil that makes magic under metal. “Fox,” he said, without preamble, proud as if he had made the animal out of spare buttons and ingenuity. She made a sound on the line that was half laugh and half old country blessing. “Good,” she said. “Now do not get cocky and look for wolf. There is arrogance and then there is foolishness.”

“I fixed a light,” he said, and then laughed at himself because he had become someone whose updates were wildlife and bulbs, and he loved that for himself. He told her about the dome and about Jacques and the knitting, and she told him about how at Safeway they had moved the pickles to the other side of the aisle and she had stood there for an embarrassing amount of time thinking that perhaps the world had ended. When he hung up he had the feeling he had after successfully making a ground connection in an old house—relief, hum, stability.

By the time they pulled into Sudbury Junction, a name that sounded like a person you might date in high school, the sky had gone a proper blue instead of the white that performs uncommitted impressions. Sudbury had a smokestack like a cigarette in a painting, obscene and necessary. People joined them with last-minute snow on their boots and the look of people who had just told someone they would behave and did not mean it. He stretched in the aisle with the courtesy a man gives to an aisle that has made room for his limbs. The boy with the cards had acquired a friend, and they were now playing in a way that involved slapping and shouts stifled into smaller, more train-appropriate shouts.

He met a man in the dome later with a camera lens long enough to make Chadwick Boseman’s cheekbones feel surveilled from a city away. The man spoke about light like it owed him money. “The shield,” the man said, pointing with his chin at the world as if the earth were a smaller thing that could be indicated usefully. “Ancient rock. It makes a man feel new and tired at once.”

“I fix things that pretend they want to die,” Nate said, and the man considered this politely as if he were taste-testing a metaphor, and then nodded as if it passed.

He dozed and woke and the hours compressed the way they do when you are both eager and content. He thought about the contest in a way that settled into him like good bread: heavy, satisfying, not swollen with air. The emails had clarified that there would be press and he reminded himself he could be funny enough to give the cameras something that wasn’t just a caught-in-headlights face full of pastry. He thought about the other contestants, avatars on a page he had half-stalked. A woman from Halifax who had opinions on meringue that could serve as a manifesto. A man from Calgary whose Instagram was a parade of gym and bakery and who had, inexplicably, founded a charity knitting club that made hats shaped like pies for babies. A teen from northern Quebec whose entire vibe was two parts sugar anarchist, one part grandma-approved tradition, and one part haircut that frightened mothers.

They made Toronto in the gray that city centers wear in winter—the particular gleam of wet steel, the way the light refuses to be loyal to any one building, the cold rising from the stone like a rumor of something that had happened long ago. Union Station’s platforms were caves that hummed with commerce. He stepped down into the bath of noise as if into water and felt the edges of himself come up alert. The hall was bright and loud, its fonts declaring a modernity that felt like it was politely ignoring Winnipeg’s Beaux-Arts aunt. People moved with purpose, their luggage wheels yelling their thoughts into the hollow of the ceiling. He followed the flow, a fish in a school, and found himself spat into that part of Toronto that insists it is the center of all maps—taxis and glass, buskers doing their valiant printed-scarf tricks, a woman in a coat so excellent it made his hands itch because he wanted to tell her that someone somewhere had loved her enough to hand her this and say wear it, be brilliant.

He shouldered his bag and let his body catch up with the speed of this place. He had a cheap hotel two subway stops away, a room that promised a bed and a television that would try to sell him a better mattress than the one he was lying on. He found the subway with the help of signs that were determined to be helpful in two languages and three moods, bought a pass because he liked the feeling of a card opening something, a door, a day, and stood in the train as it needed him to. Toronto under Toronto moved like a river that had learned grammar. He watched how people made room for each other and bumped anyway and apologized and sometimes didn’t. Winnipeg had taught him to make a face at this and then forgive it. He put his bag by his feet and resisted the politely feral instinct to smile at strangers because he knew here that could look like an insult or worse, an invitation.

The hotel was exactly what the internet had promised and precisely less, which meant he trusted it. The desk clerk was soft-spoken in a way that made everyone else in the lobby a bad decision. The carpet had a geometry it had not consented to. The bed was so determined to be a bed it almost apologized for its own rectangle. He dropped his bag on the chair that he wouldn’t use for anything except holding his bag because there is something about it being there that tells a room: I am not moving in, calm down. He put his hand on the window and felt the city through the glass, a hum across his skin, and thought about calling his mother and decided to check in with the part of him that had come all this way. He sat on the bed, folded in the middle where the cheap mattress confessed itself, and took out the bib. He had told himself he wouldn’t wear it in the mirror because that felt like tempting fate on the level of telling a house you didn’t like its wallpaper. He draped it over the chair instead. The wheat sheaf in the corner. A Manitoban banner that looked like it had not been drawn by a committee but by a hand that understood wheat as the emblem not of quaintness but of a stubborn insistence on life.

He walked down to the venue later because walking is how you reclaim a city from your nerves. It was a market space turned competition hall, lights strung so that it looked like a wedding had agreed to accommodate sport. The stage had three long tables bracketed by cameras like curious geese. Volunteers in t-shirts the color of victory moved with the helpfulness that comes with being fed and appreciated. He found Drew at a registration table framed by a display of fonts. Drew’s eyebrows lifted when he saw him, the quiet satisfaction of a spreadsheet reconciled and an old man’s story about the dome car confirmed. “You made it,” he said, as if conferring an achievement rather than narrating a fact.

He signed where he was told to sign and read what he was told to read and adopted his laminated badge with the light embarrassment that comes from wearing your own name under your face. “Media run-through at ten,” a bright volunteer named Frankie told him cheerfully. “Interview after your heat. We’re rescue dogs with hydration if you need it. And yes, the pies are identical. That question comes up more than hearts can bear.”

He walked the floor and felt the particular shiver that comes from all the electricity in a room being eager at once. He stood at the edge where his table would be, looked at the row of plates he was allowed to consider as instruments and not just plates, at the stack of napkins, at the little display that indicated that some part of this would be pretend. He thought of the boy with the cards and of Jacques and of the fox. He thought of the light in the snack car and of the little horse tail that had been persuaded to return to a destiny it had wandered away from. He could feel the part of him that wanted to take this all too seriously, the part that believed that the way you do any small thing is the way you will do it all and that therefore this mattered like a proof of character. He gently sent that part of himself to sit in the corner and watch. He would let another part of himself—the one that had laughed with his face purpled by Saskatoons—hold the forkless instrument of his absurd craft.

His phone buzzed while he was standing there, absorbing the very idea of Toronto being willing to make room for a prairie man’s minor glory. His mother had sent a picture of his kitchen window with the note: I watered the plant. It looked at me like a suspect. He smiled back at the image as if it could feel him. Gertie sent a voice memo that was ninety percent bracelets clinking and ten percent, “Remember: mouth like a machine and heart like a poet.” He received a text from the Winnipeg Agricultural Society that consisted entirely of a cartoon sheaf of wheat lifting a tiny barbell. Raj sent, succinctly, run the table.

He took a breath the way the good runners do, not in his throat but in his ribs. He let them hold the ladder because that was part of what had kept him human here—hands under things, hands on rails, hands that did not pull but steadied.
