The horn cut the idea in half and they bent. Butter tart again, of course, the final meant to be the same as the test in case the narrative of practice had any moral weight. It was instinct now and not calculation. He let himself be a metronome with habits. He thought of fox and mint and dome and all of it dropped like pennies into the deep jar of his body and did what pennies do there—made a dense song of small metal statements. There were yells; there were the helpful cries of people with signs; there was the particular sound a volunteer with a camera makes when they realize they are in the shot and must back up both eagerly and discreetly. There was his own breath, steady itself and asking only for the simple kindness of being given a plan. He was giving it one. He let his mouth be shameless and his heart be tender and his hands be still in view of everyone to satisfy the rule.

He lost track of the minute marks in a way that did not bother him because he was not living this to make time his pet but to prove to himself he could inhabit eight minutes without backing out. He thought of his mother’s socks in his bag and of the man with the camera on the train and of Jacques’s story about the bloody ticket. He kept eating. He kept going. The horn at the end was a mercy and a surprise and a sting because endings always have a little of that in them, even when they arrive on schedule.

They put their napkins down with too much dignity, which made the thing funny rather than sad. The judges conferred for longer than he thought necessary but necessary is not a measure that belongs to joy. He did not look at the screen for the replay that would show him doing a thing that looked both braver and sillier than he had felt; he kept his eyes on the little pattern in the paper napkin under his glass because small designs had saved him before, in kitchens and in halls and inside panels, when he needed to remember that the world had been arranged thoughtfully by someone, at some point, and therefore could be borne.

They announced Moira third and the room cheered in the way a room cheers a woman who has comported herself as if she has nothing to prove until suddenly she does and then proves only the thing she chooses. They announced his name second and he felt the swallow in his throat do complicated good work. He took the yellow ribbon they had printed for second and let it be what it was—beautiful and a little ridiculous—and he grinned in a way that made his cheeks ache. Élodie’s name for first made a clean sound in the air and she startled as if someone had set off a harmless firework two inches from her ear. She covered her mouth with her hand and then, as if she had been instructed by a grandmother in a dream about how to behave when praise refuses to be coy, she uncovered it and wiped her cheeks and let herself be photographed like someone proving that they would not waste this.

There was noise. There were microphones. There was a man from the Agricultural Society who had somehow made it to Toronto with a wheat pin in his lapel and damp eyes that he pretended were about the travel. There were texts. There was a hand on his shoulder, warm and firm, that he knew before he turned belonged to Drew, who had the look of a facilitator whose spreadsheet had become a parade. There was a volunteer pressing a bottle of water into his palm as if he had run a race, as if this counted, and he knew it did, in the way that we assign weight to frivolities when they gather enough laughter around them.

He did the interviews again and did them better because he had practice and because his heart had done some work on the train with strangers. He told a man with a tape recorder that he loved the moment a silly thing and sincerity meet, that he would go home with a small second-place thing in his bag and that it would clutter his shelf in a way that could only improve the room. He told a woman with glasses that he had almost not come and that the universal fact of the world is that the trains exist and the people who help you buy tickets exist and if you are lucky there is pie at the end but if there isn’t then there is still the dome and Jacques and fox and the peppermint that tells your heart to quiet down.

He got away, finally, escaping the stage by walking in plain sight like a man carrying a ladder in a room full of people who instinctively make way for someone with a tool. He found the quiet of a staircase that led nowhere anyone important would be going and sat with his ribbon in his lap and let himself be tired. His phone buzzed evenly, a string of congratulations from numbers that had found him, some belonging to people he would never meet who had decided for a day to take him into their possession as a thing to root for, the way cities allot themselves small saints for seasonal devotion. He answered what he could and allowed the rest to belong to the room, to the event, to the part of his life that would live a while online without him. He texted Raj a picture of himself with Élodie and Moira and the three of them holding up their little tokens with honesty and not a lick of mockery. Raj replied with a photo of Mrs. Banerjee’s dog wearing, inexplicably, a paper crown, and the words: you remain intolerable in all the best ways.

He called his mother and she answered with the sound of her house behind her, the kettle pretending it had always been boiling. “Second,” he said, and there was a beat exactly as long as a cheer being gathered and then let go.

“Second is heaven,” she said. “First is a feast you cannot digest before people come asking for recipes. Second is food you can put in containers and eat all week. I am proud. Also, a woman in line in front of me just tried to use a debit card that did not exist and everyone decided to forgive her. Winnipeg sends you forgiveness and beets.”

He almost said he had seen a fox again because he wanted to live in a world with omens, but he had not and he would not lie to make a story give him better gifts. He told her instead the truth of the peppermints and of Moira’s braid and of the boy with the cards on the train and she made approving noises at all the right places. He did not notice until afterward that he had given her very little about the pie itself and much about the people, and that seemed right. The pie had been a structure to house the real work, which was attention.

By the time he stepped out into Toronto’s evening, the city had put its jewelry back on. Light climbed up buildings in stacks and made people look like they had been asked to play versions of themselves and had agreed. He walked toward his hotel because there was nothing left to do except what there always is—eat something worthy, drink water, sleep. He found, on the way, a small place that advertised Ukrainian food with less embarrassment than he had expected and the kind of plastic-cut plant in the window that told him someone inside had decided to be tidy about hope. He went in. He ate borscht that tasted like a memory written by someone else’s aunt and perogies that were less delicate than his mother’s and more frank than his. He sat with his ribbon in his pocket and did not take it out because it took up exactly the right amount of space where it was. He left a tip he could afford and thought about how sometimes spending a little on something after a win is not bad stewardship but celebration, and that too is a skill a man can learn without collapsing anything useful inside himself.

Back in the room, he put the ribbon on the cheap dresser with the wheat bib under it and the effect, to his eye, was ridiculous and perfect. He took a picture of it and did not send it to anyone because he wanted one image to belong only to him. He brushed his teeth for a long time and then again because the butter tart had declared a residency and he was the landlord. He lay down and felt the city under him, the hum that was not his but that he could borrow. He had the thought, just before sleep took his hand and led him through a door, that he would fix the humming light again at the snack bar if asked and that there was something in that impulse that mattered more than any ribbon ever would. He dreamed of trains and of small horses with mended tails running beside them, unafraid of the noise, sure of the track because someone in the car above was holding a ladder for someone else and the light, when tested, did not flicker.

Chapter 7

Winnipeg took him back the way a good coat takes you back when you shrug into it—without commentary, with a few familiar creaks, with the smell of thaw embedded in the lining. March had decided to rehearse at the edges, streaking the snowbanks with a graying that looked like the city’s five o’clock shadow. On the boulevards, rinds of ice loosened their grip and the gutters began their annual soliloquy, water gossiping toward drains like it had a great deal to tell. The van started on the second try and Nate took it personally as a love letter he would not overinterpret, and he drove to his first job after Toronto with a ribbon in the glove box that he had already forgotten, twice, and then found again as if finding it were part of the bargain.

The job was at a community rink in St. James where the lights, as the caretaker put it, were “deciding to be poets about illumination.” The fixtures hung from rafters that had seen a generation of fathers teach a generation of children to wobble confidently; the wood had the long, dry smell of a place you don’t mind breathing in. He had been told, on the phone, that sometimes three lights went at once and sometimes two and sometimes they took turns winking like aunties who did not approve but adored. He parked by the chain-link fence where someone had tied scarves in team colors and where a handmade sign scolded: NO SLAPSHOTS DURING PUBLIC SKATE, which was the sort of rule this city wrote with affection that dared you to sulk.

Inside, the ice hissed gently under floodlights that were not quite up to the task, and a man in a jacket that bore the rink’s crest approached as if hoping an electrician might also be a priest. “They’re old ballasts,” the man said, as if confessing that his house had dial-up internet. “We got a grant for half and then the rest was supposed to be bake sales, and then the bake sales became a fight about whether oatmeal counts as a cookie, which, frankly, it does not.”

“I will refrain from official rulings,” Nate said, and looked up into the rafters with the squint of a man estimating both the cost and the stories. The metal housings had been installed in a rush sometime around the last millennium and had never forgiven anyone for it, and he could see where tape—honest, earnest, foolish tape—had been asked to serve as philosophy. He fetched his ladder from the van, the one with aluminum scuffs up its ribs from a winter’s worth of Winnipeg interiors, and when he returned to the boards there were three dads and one mom already standing in formation because there is nothing about a rink that does not invite a person to be useful.

He let them hold the ladder because that was part of what had kept him human here—hands under things, hands on rails, hands that did not pull but steadied. He climbed and coaxed the housings open with the measured sweetness of a man convincing a cornered cat to exit a cupboard. Behind him the rink’s air carried the smell of old coffee and a child’s wool hat and the particular metallic note of skates that have learned to take compliments. The ballasts had a sulk to them he recognized, the low, intermittent hum like a teenager preparing to apologize without ever intending to use the word sorry. He tapped and tightened and then replaced what needed replacing, and he did it with the mild ceremony he reserved for this sort of repair, because the repair mattered less than the theater of calm it brought with it and everyone in the stands needed that swallow of quiet as much as they needed light.

When the fixtures came up, one and then three and then, grudgingly, five, the ice looked like it had forgiven the day. A cheer went up on the benches that was mostly children and partly adults who remembered, suddenly, being children, and the sound made him grin into the metal like a man being told by a stranger that the thing he loved about himself had been noticed. He came down the ladder to mitts offered in the shape of reward, paper cups pressed toward him like sacrament, coffee and chocolate in equal measure, and a woman in a toque with a pom-pom the size of a domestic cat said, “You fixed our winter,” with a sincerity that should have embarrassed them all and did not.

He took his payment in a folded check that would not bounce and a dozen coupons for rink burgers that he suspected might be the kind of food that required youth to digest. He tucked the check into his wallet and the coupons into his pocket and let them make his hip feel like it had work to do, and he stood a minute longer at the boards to watch a boy in a red sweater gain the kind of balance that will make him trustworthy when he is fifteen. On his way out, the caretaker pressed a flyer into his hand and cocked his head like a bird asking if seed was still free. “Spring Thaw Pie-Off is posting their judges on Friday,” the man said, out of nowhere, as if gossip had moved up into the ducts. “You get to Toronto and back and the rumor is they might ask you to sit and nod and make pronouncements with a fork.”

He shrugged the way men shrug when they have something small and excitable inside their chest and do not want the world to poke it. “I have a face that can nod,” he said. “I practiced on trains.”

At the Blue Goose later, Gertie had reorganized the front case so it faced the door with a belligerent prettiness. The pies were unapologetic circles dressed in golden armor, and there was a new sign bravely lettered by someone whose handwriting improved dramatically when they were told everyone would see it. SPRING THAW PATRON SAINTS, the top read, and then it listed names that were either legendary bakers or coworkers willing to be teased, and there, at the bottom, small and serious, was: N. KOWALSKY, LOCAL BOY, JAWS OF LIFE. He stood in the doorway with his hat in his hands and laughed, and the laugh eased something in him that had tightened on the drive into town when the sun took that watery angle between buildings that told you winter was eavesdropping.

“You are a minor religion,” Gertie said, from behind the counter, measuring cinnamon with the severity of a person ordering the behavior of stars. “We have candles. We have devotions. We do not yet have indulgences but we are working on it. Sit and tell me about the dome again, because I am a woman who can listen to the same story twelve times if the verbs behave.”

He told her and didn’t tell her, not because he was precious but because stories have layers and he wanted to let this one peel at its own pace. He told her about Jacques and his nose and his mother and doughnuts; he told her about the peppermint and about the boy with the cards; he told her he had fixed a light, and when he said that she made the kind of sound a person makes when listening to a wedding and someone says the right name. He didn’t tell her about the way he had seen his mother’s hands in his own when he steadied the ladder for the house tech in Toronto, because some things were best carried a while before being laid on a counter and offered as dessert, and he knew she would be there when he was ready to talk.

By the register, there was an envelope with his name on it in handwriting that knew the weight of a fountain pen. He raised his eyebrows and Gertie nodded like a magician refusing to reveal the mechanics. “Agricultural Society,” she said, as if she were saying the Saints or the Weather. “He said he is not finished interfering in your life, but only on months with an R in them.”

Inside the envelope was a note on heavy paper that tried to be casual and fumbled, and a voucher from a local credit union with numbers on it he could read and pretend not to be amazed by. They wanted him to “host” a slice-and-sip night at the Fair’s spring fundraiser, which turned out to be exactly what it sounded like—adults with plastic cups of apple cider watching a man eat pie with technique, and then asking him questions about breath as if breath were a currency that might appreciate if they understood it. He felt, reading it, something that was not quite dread and not quite thrill but the good neighbor of both, the feeling you have when you walk out on thin ice you know to be trustworthy because you saw yesterday’s footprints and the surface held.

He said yes of course in a way that implied he was a man who had been waiting for precisely this kind of absurdity. He marked the date in his book where he kept columns for what needed bolts and what needed talk. He had to finish the rink for the weekend, he had a laundry list of basements, he had the professional pleasure of a St. Vital bungalow whose owner had over-loved his dimmers until they became confessional, and amidst them all he now had to find a way to be a person who could stand in a room and let people look without deciding to hide behind a ladder. He could do it, he told himself, because he had done it, in an arena that smelled like caramel and judgment, and if he could do it there he could do it wearing a flannel shirt that had survived drywall.

The days installed themselves like switch plates. He pulled wire along joists in a crawlspace that had heard stories and kept them; he replaced a burnt-out breaker for a woman who insisted on giving him a mason jar of pickled beets as if electricity and beets could be stirred into the same stew and improve each other; he let a cat sniff his shoes and decide, finally, that he was not a threat, and the decision gratified him in a way he couldn’t explain. Each night, the ribbon on his dresser nudged his eye and then let him look away, and some afternoons he would let his thumb slide the satin like a touch meant to confirm not pride but texture, and he thought of Jacques’s punched tickets and the small snow of paper circles on the carpet.

There was weather, dramatic and unamused. A wet snow blew in on a Thursday, the kind that makes you understand why your boots exist, and then the temperature fell with the confidence of a headline. Winnipeg did what it always does—it pulled its scarf up, it turned its face into wind in a posture of dignified defiance, it compensated. The calls that came in were a string of ordinary emergencies—GFCIs that had decided fear would be their personality, furnace blowers that forgot their manners, basement lights that asked to be translated back into function—and he spent a day moving from house to house like a stethoscope pressed to the city’s chest, and he found he loved his day for its quiet competence. In the evening he got a text from an unknown number that turned out to be Moira, the braid woman, with a picture of a plate and a silver fork and the caption: Halifax insists we remain hungry, and he laughed because he understood what it was to be fond of a city and critical and to blend the two into a meal.

“Judges,” Drew texted, with an attachment that was a PDF that had been designed by someone who believed in boxes. “Friday noon. Wear scarves. There will be microphones. We’ll be kind.”

He told his mother because she had a right to know when her son’s mouth had been officially invited to have opinions for a crowd. “Do not wear black shirts,” she said, practical and grave. “It makes crumbs look like confession. Wear blue so when you say wise things about crust people will believe you and also because it suits your eyes, even if you pretend you do not know this about yourself.” He rolled his own eyes at himself for smiling and then did as he was told.

He walked to The Forks in a wind that had given up the argument for spring and opted instead to show everyone the shape of their cheeks. The festival had changed outfits, trading Saskatoon blues for the clean brown of butter and nuts, and the judges’ table looked less like a stage and more like a long family argument with forks. He sat between a woman from a radio show who had opinions about nutmeg and the director of a local theater who had arrived with the body language of a man prepared to be surprised. Frankie slid him a clipboard with scoring rubrics that were both earnest and insane—crust flake was a category, as was something called “structural moral argument,” and he appreciated the city for tossing its weight behind a joke until the joke offered to pay rent. He took his job seriously in the sense that when he bit he closed his eyes because it felt impolite not to, and he described, when asked, a crust as “honest work” and a filling as “the right kind of apology,” and afterward a woman in the crowd stopped him and said, “I felt like you were talking about my ex-husband,” which he did not know how to take and therefore took as a victory.

On the way home, he passed the municipal library where children were stacked in parkas on the carpet watching a man make shadow puppets convincing enough to make a ladybug terrifying. He cut down a side street where ice at the curb had decided it would be glass until June, and there he saw Mrs. Banerjee in a hat that made her look like a fancy teapot. The dog wore a sweater that might once have been a sock. She lifted her glove as if flagging a taxi, and in doing so accidentally signaled him to a stop.

“I saw you on the television,” she said, and the way she said television made it sound like an oracle that resided in a cabinet. “I am amused that we live in a society that will put a man under lights to discuss crust, and also I have notes.”

“Of course you do,” he said, and bent to greet the dog, who pretended to tolerate him as part of a long con wherein one day Nate would be allowed to scratch the belly. “Do I get a letter grade.”

“You get an A when you remember that adjectives were invented by people who disapproved of nouns,” she said, severe and fond. “Do not be kind at the expense of truth. Also, your van door squeaks and everyone on this block believes it is the bird that starts spring at five thirty.”

“I will oil it,” he said. “I will oil it with civic pride.”

She narrowed her eyes and then smiled because it is difficult to remain stern when someone volunteers to improve a hinge for the common good. “Good,” she said. “The dog assumes spring is your fault and will ask you for an accounting when the snow returns on Tuesday.”

He was halfway up his steps when his phone buzzed with a number that made him forget his key was in his hand. VIA RAIL, the screen declared with the impersonal punctuation of bureaucracy and the friendliness of a vacation timeline. He answered out of habit and curiosity, and a voice that could have belonged to any of the country’s train stations said a series of words that lined up into a surprise—customer appreciation, travel voucher, previous purchase, feedback call, random draw. He waited for a catch and could not find one except the kind that catches you at the sternum when life, at long intervals, conspires to repay you in symbols.

“We have a voucher you may use within twelve months,” the woman said, professional and ever so slightly pleased on his behalf. “It is our way of saying that time is not always an enemy and sometimes an ally, and that duct tape is not a solution on our trains but is perhaps a reasonable metaphor.”

He laughed because he couldn’t not, because the world had decided to be kind in a way that would be a story and he was in the mood for stories. He took the number and wrote it in his book with a pen that had been to Toronto and back, and he thought of Sudbury and the fox and Jacques and the napkin that purchased sorrow, and he felt that quiet expansion inside that is not joy exactly but is its cousin—something like faith, except it involves fewer declarations.

The Fair’s slice-and-sip turned out to be an event only a town that believes in itself could devise. There were twinkle lights and earnest chairs and paper plates printed with harvest scenes, and a man with a banjo in the corner making gentle noises so that the room would remember to smile. Nate stood with a plate and an absurdly long fork someone had lent him for theatrical effect, and at first he did the thing where he made small jokes to protect himself, and then he let the jokes go because he realized he had a room full of people who had decided to be generative rather than critical. He talked not about speed but about attention and about the discipline of breathing and about how he once had learned that strip, twist, cap was as close as he would get to a lullaby. He spoke about ladders, god help him, and the holding of them for other people, and midway through a sentence he saw a man in the back lower his head like someone who had just remembered being saved by something modest, and he knew he had said something true in public and not been punished.

After, people came up with their questions and their stories and their auntie’s recipes that required lard and a good marriage, and a girl of about seven with hair in the romantic state of perpetual tangles said, “I want to be a fixer like you but with cakes,” and he said, “Good, then it will be easier to get invited to parties,” and her mother laughed and he felt, with body-surety, that his city was a series of rooms where he could tell the truth about small things and not be corrected.

Work continued to be a constellation of domestic dramas in need of practical endings. He went to a St. Boniface duplex where a new father had decided to rewire a nursery in the week before his child’s arrival because mortality had arrived on the porch with a diaper bag, and he held the man’s fear without putting his hands directly on it and showed him where to staple and where not to staple and said the words it is okay to hire help out loud so that the man would not have to extract his pride from under a refrigerator later. He went to a Norwood Park bungalow and installed under-cabinet lighting for a woman who had inherited her mother’s cookbooks and had decided to live inside them for a while, and they talked about cardamom like it was a plot twist that proves the writer knows what she’s doing. He went to a bank’s back office where the breaker panel had been labeled by someone with a sense of humor and no handwriting, and he hung new labels and made them boring on purpose so that no one would one day pull the wrong thing in a hurry because whimsy had been allowed to masquerade as a schematic.

He heard from Élodie in a message full of abbreviations and exclamation marks that read like a song, and she sent him a picture of her with an elderly woman in a kitchen where the counter had seen tomatoes for fifty years, and she wrote, we’re starting a youth pie club because why not and because teens should have knife skills and lungs, and he wrote back with a sincerity that did not feel like an intrusion, and he sent her a picture of the rink under lights with skate lines like a secret language. Moira mailed him a peppermint because some people take a bit and make it a ritual, and when he opened the envelope his kitchen smelled briefly like a gift shop in a town with an ethic.

On a Wednesday he drove out of town on a job whose address included the name of a road that had not decided whether it wanted to be gravel or virtue. A farmer had called, an older couple who had the voices of two people who had been weathered into kindness by work, and their barn’s wiring made the man’s nephew, an apprentice welder, nervous. He trundled up a drive that had ruts like biographies and parked by a house that had, over the years, been added to and apologized for in equal measure. The barn stood like a solemn animal and inside it the light swung from a beam where a swallow would be a minister come summer. He found splices that had been emergency solutions in an era when emergencies lasted decades, and he found cobwebs so dense he felt he owed them rent, and he replaced and tightened and put in a GFCI where a handwashing sink had been added and ignored by the gods. The farmer’s wife brought him coffee so strong it could have worked nights, and she knew the names of the cats by sight and of the cows by hoof, and she told him about the time the hydro had gone out and the milk had not and how they had relied on the fussy diesel generator like a cousin who could be counted on to complain while saving your life.

He finished at twilight when the fields around them had returned to their idea of themselves—flat with insistence, not empty but ready. The farmer gave him a sack of potatoes because payment comes in many shapes here, and as he drove back to the city the sky did a performance of colors that would have embarrassed the Pacific, and he thought about the voucher sitting in his book and the trains that would cut this very field in a line you could navigate by if the sun forgot you. He did not know where he would go, not exactly, but the ticket felt like a sentence you put on your tongue to practice saying it without flinching: I can leave and I can come back, and both are mine.

He was at the Blue Goose the next morning, because some mornings belonged to rituals and raisin toast and opinions spoken over sugar. Gertie had put out a pie that looked like a hymn, lattice so careful it could have passed inspection at a parade, and he ate without rushing because the hour did not stare at him. A boy at the counter that he did not recognize and yet knew—ridiculous hoodie, eyes that were part suspicion and part offer—watched him with the curiosity of someone deciding which older men were allowed in the neighborhood of their hopes. “You the pie guy,” the boy said, not a question but not an accusation either, and Nate, because he had decided somewhere between Sudbury and home that he would not be stingy with joy even when addressed by its teenage dialect, said, “I am a man who did a ridiculous thing and was rewarded with a ribbon, yes.”

The boy considered and then nodded as if awarding legitimacy. “Cool,” he said. “I thought it was dumb and then my aunt was like, no, this is community, and I was like, okay, and then I cried a little but I will not talk about that here.”

“Good,” Nate said, and lifted his mug in a salute to the great emotional economy of small admissions. “When you want to talk about it not here, find me, because that is also community.”

He left the diner with a pie for his mother wrapped in paper that had been driven crazy by cinnamon, and he walked up his block under a sky that had finally, finally decided to learn brightness again, and he could feel the city lifting half an inch with him, because when the cold lets go there is a humility to the air that makes you forgive your own fingers. The van door squeaked once to remind him he owned oil and then stopped because he owned oil. He mounted the steps and found, tucked into the corner of his storm door like a confession, an envelope with a Calgary postmark and a handwriting like a man trying to behave and failing gracefully. Inside was a postcard with a picture of the world’s largest perogy, which was a joke that did not know whether to be affectionate or ashamed, and Ty had written on the back: man, the kids at the gym made me eat blueberry protein “pie” and it was a crime; I told them you’re the guy who would hold a ladder for a stranger and that is what heroes are; you coming west one day, you have a couch here and a pie club that wears weights. He propped the card against his salt shaker and wondered at the way the world had enlarged itself around him without demanding that he be louder.

That evening, after his calls had been logged and his receipts shoved into the diplomatic pouch of a man’s pockets, Raj came by with beer and a story about a client who had paid him in a painting of her late dachshund and a bowl of grapes. They sat on the floor because the couch was still a project he had not finished budgeting for, and they leaned their heads back against the wall like kids who had ditched class and somehow ended up in a sanctified space. “You have a voucher,” Raj said, and said it with the satisfaction of a man for whom instruments of mobility were almost erotic. “We are a people of coupons and opportunity. Where do you want to go.”

“Not west,” Nate said, because he had already arranged for west to be a later gift. “Maybe east and not Toronto, something smaller. A town where trains are not an event but a pulse. Or north a little, where the trees remember things I do not. Or maybe nowhere and then somewhere when the word shows up on my tongue and fits.”

“Good,” Raj said. “I enjoy that travel can be grammatical. You know, the dog wore a paper crown the day you won because Mrs. Banerjee did not have a ribbon and decided that monarchy could stand in.”

“I hope she burned the crown when the snow came back,” Nate said, and they both watched the window where their reflections sat with them like sudden guests, thin and earnest. For a time they were quiet the way men are quiet when love is too large for language but under no threat, and then they began the chew of trivialities again because triviality is sometimes how you protect what matters.

When the call came on Friday, he was in a utility room in a building that smelled like old plants and new promises, and he let it go to voicemail because breakers do not like to be ignored in their hour of need. Later, in the van, he pressed the triangle and listened to Drew explain in his familiar blend of authority and invitation that the National Sweet had decided to film a special about “regional saints” and wanted to come to Winnipeg and ask him to help them not make a fool of themselves. “We are good at reverence,” Drew said, words crisp and amused. “They are good at cameras. Let’s see if we can make a meal that won’t embarrass the aunts.”

He stared at the windshield for an extravagant number of seconds because his brain was busy organizing itself into yes. He thought about his town’s patience, about how cameras can be both magnifying and cruel, about the way he could put his body between a camera and something truly tender and say you may look but you will not take. He thought about the lights at the rink and the peppermint and the way Élodie had not softened her face until praise required it, and he thought that perhaps what he had been practicing all winter—breath and stance and the permission to be joyful about small absurdities—had been a rehearsal for a thing he had not named. He dialed and said yes in a voice that sounded like someone tightening a screw to the exact snugness it needed, and then he put the van in gear and joined the afternoon the way you join a crowd that is moving in a direction you are happy to be going, admiring the coats, making sure your own zipper is up, grateful for elbows and for the way your city knows your stride.

Chapter 9

The film crew arrived on a Wednesday that looked like it had practiced its sincerity in the mirror. The snowbanks had been cut down into low gray loaves, the gutters were muttering to themselves with purpose, and geese flew overhead like punctuation, correcting the sentences winter had written all over the river. The email had called them a unit—production unit, as if they were a battalion—but the people who stepped off the shuttle and into the light had the look of individuals who had learned to share snacks and grudges on long drives. The showrunner was named Tessa and wore a coat like an intention. The cameraman, Lionel, had knees that told you he’d crouched in the cold for a living, and a lens he touched the way other men touched heirlooms, careful and amused at the attention they were getting for their care. Yasmin, the sound op, had hair that dared the wind to try and was the sort of person who says hello to a building’s exterior before going in. Behind them all trailed a young person in a wool hat with a clipboard—the universal badge of someone’s newness and competence—whose name was Courtney and who chewed on the cap of a pen with the concentration of a squirrel saving up character.

Drew met them with a laminated schedule and the calm of a person who knew how to move authority around until it looked like a friendly party. He pointed at Nate as if presenting a tool he was especially proud of. “Our local,” he said, which sounded like a role and also like something a bar keeps on tap for loyalists. Tessa shook Nate’s hand and did the quick, efficient scan of a face that television people did, assessing angles, comfort, the likelihood a person will collapse into adjectives. “We want to show your city as itself,” she said, and he heard the italics and did not resent them because at least she knew italics existed. “We want the room to feel like the room. Help us not build a bad prairie diorama. Help us not embarrass the aunts.”

“I can be a very bossy nephew,” he said, and she laughed and then looked relieved when he didn’t take the joke farther than necessary.

They had a list of locations that began as guesswork and ended as a map only someone who lived here could draw. The Blue Goose, of course, because you don’t make a show about sugar in this city and ignore the room where opinions were plated and the coffee was more policy than beverage. The community rink in St. James, where the lights had been saved from their own drama and where children learned to wobble into competence under a ceiling that had not fallen in anyone’s lifetime. His mother’s kitchen had been proposed and retired gently because his mother had said on the phone, in the tone of someone directing traffic at a parade, that cameras would eat her curtains and she did not have new curtains to feed them. She would allow her hands, though, and a bowl, and what she called “the part of my forearm where you can see the life I have lived,” and the sound op had said she could work with that and made a note that read hands/forearm/soup in block letters because sometimes you have to say exactly what you mean to the future.

They began at the diner because that was the kind of statement television liked—place and person, smell of cinnamon pretending to be narrative, the visual generosity of glass cases. Gertie stood behind the counter with a posture she normally reserved for the mayor and people who attempted to bargain down the cost of lemon meringue. She had put on earrings that might have been small golden pies or, depending on your faith, suns. The crew did the introductions with the careful humility of people entering a kitchen they did not own. Tessa began to explain what they wanted and Gertie lifted a hand delicately, palm open like an air traffic instruction.

“You will not put jaunty music over my pies,” she said, with the crispness of a kitchen towel snapped into purpose. “You will not call me an institution as if I were a building that pretends to not crave repainting. You may ask me about butter and I will tell you truths you can live by, and you may ask me about men who think pie is a hobby and I will tell you a different set of truths that you may decide are unairable. You will eat and you will not put your fork down on the plate with the tines facing up because we are not animals.”

Yasmin’s mouth did the quick gymnastics of someone suppressing a laugh because she had learned to treat sound the way a librarian treats quiet. Tessa nodded, throat working, the way a person nods when they realize they’ve been handed the manual for the equipment they have just plugged in without reading the manual. “No jaunty music,” she said. “No institutions. Butter and men as subjects. Fork etiquette. Understood.”

Nate watched the exchange with the pleasure of a man who had been asked to be useful and found the work being done for him by someone who had more glamorous verbs. He took Lionel to the back to show him where he could get a shot of the ovens without also getting a shot of the mop bucket, because documentary truth did not require audiences to know the color of the mop water. He taped down cables with the gentle roughly of someone who had spent a winter falling over the wrong things, and he moved one of the suppler power bars off a circuit that also powered the ice cream freezer, because a scoop’s noble work need not be imperiled by television.

They chased light that day like responsible thieves. Tessa wanted a shot of the river path and the warming huts, those small pieces of art that appeared on the ice each year like confidence. The trail had turned into a memory with a half-life and the signs had gone up advising people who weren’t from here to be their best selves and stay off. Nate made a call to a friend of Raj’s who worked with the festival that brought the huts and secured permission to film one dragged up on land, tilted like a question. They loaded pies like relics and staged an argument between pies and weather, and it looked better on screen than anyone expected, which is how this city rewarded persistence: not with drama, but with a kind of crooked cooperativeness.

At the rink, the caretaker smiled like a man evaluating suitors and pointed at the paper sign about slapshots, which someone had fortified with glitter and conviction. Parents had been warned; forms had been printed and actual pens had been found. Children skated as if they were being filmed by a kind god and then forgot the camera existed and became their knees again. The crew wanted a sequence of the lights coming on, the way rooms change when illumination remembers itself, and Nate told them he would not fake the flicker. He would not stand people in a fabricated darkness so that their joy could be manufactured. He asked the caretaker to hit the switch at the natural hour and they waited in the seam time between gray and blaze, breathing into their mitts. When the lights came, three and one and then the rest in their obedient train, the rink made a kind of sound that didn’t need microphones. Yasmin checked her levels anyway and Lionel grinned through his viewfinder as if he’d been given permission to keep the contentment.

There were moments when the show tried to be a show and the city tried to be a city and Nate had to wedge himself between the two to make introductions more polite. At Union Station, the production wanted a shot of him in profile under the arch, looking like a man cultivates myth in his spare time. There was no train that hour, only a maintenance crew with carts and common sense, and someone suggested the Railway Museum as a stand-in with better angles. He shook his head because the performative image of a man with a ticket and an expression would not be truer for being prettier. He pointed out, instead, a small corner by the coffee kiosk where the sun shot a ribbon across the floor at ten thirty and made anyone who walked through it look like a lead in a movie about decency. They filmed him there, buying a coffee and not spilling it, nodding to the kind woman who tucked his change with the grace of practice into a dish, and the clip would later make people write to the show and say that they had, themselves, been there at ten thirty on a Wednesday and had felt better for it, and could they buy that feeling somewhere.

His mother agreed to hands, and to forearm, and to a bowl that had cracked and been mended, and the camera loved her the way cameras love people who do not ask to be looked at. She wore an apron with a pattern of cherries that had seen more grease than church, and she let flour be flour and not a symbol. Elastic dough flopped with the sound of a thing willing to be worked, and her voice, when it came as an invitation to the ear and not the eye, made even the clipboard-pen keepers stand still. She told a story about learning to say the word for stove in English and saying store by mistake and ending up with a bag that smelled like rubber and choices. Tessa asked permission, quietly, to use her line about media being a mirror that distorts because it is a mirror, and his mother said she could use it if she also added that sometimes mirrors are for checking if your teeth have parsley in them and this is a kindness. They laughed, and Lionel’s camera made gentle confessions about where it liked to stand.

There was one moment—the fight had to arrive somewhere—when someone from production, an assistant to a person who had not come to Winnipeg because they were guarding a spreadsheet in Toronto, sent notes that suggested they stage a scene of winter hardship by frosting an exterior window and having Nate scrape it in a way that aligned with a sentimental narrative about ruggedness. “We can blow snow,” Tessa said, apologetic already, holding up her phone with the email on it like a curse she had not sworn. “We can suggest marrow-stiffening adversity. They want grit. Grit sells.”

“We have grit,” he said, and did not mean the show kind. “But frost is not a metaphor until you’ve watched your own breath hang in a hallway because the furnace fan died and you have five minutes to decide whether to learn or to call. We have perfectly serviceable adversity. We don’t need to counterfeit it. Let me show you a lever that sticks unless you talk to it right. Let me introduce you to the sound the ice makes when it’s lying about its integrity. Let me tell your camera to wait with us at a bus stop when the sign says fifteen minutes and the wind says thirty. Or we can point the lens at a bowl of soup and admit that heat is a kind of miracle.”

Yasmin nodded the way people nod when an argument sets itself down with its weight where it belongs. Tessa put her phone back in her coat and changed the plan by not writing the change down. The fake frost did not happen. They recorded his hands on a real lever and the lever, flattered by the attention, behaved, and the part of the audience that had grown up in houses with levers wrote later to say thank you for not telling lies about their childhoods.

The only real crisis of the week had a smell—ozone and anxiety. At the Blue Goose on Friday, halfway through a setup for a shot that would involve pie cooling on a sill like a fairy tale that had decided to be practical, a circuit popped somewhere in the subtle geometry of the building and half the front room’s lights narrowed themselves for a debate about whether illumination should be optional. The coffee machine made a sound like a polite cough that refuses to escalate to a scene. Lionel looked up at the ceiling with the instinct of a man who had forgotten his luck was dependent on electrons. Gertie put her hands on her hips as if rearranging them might rearrange modernity. The show’s gaffer, who was there to wrangle light in an elevated sense and not to negotiate with a café’s secret temper, peered into a junction box with the brave disinterest of someone smelling another trade’s territory.

Nate had already moved. He crouched behind the counter with the familiarity of a cousin who knows where the holiday cutlery is kept and popped the panel to see that a breaker had done its job and that the job had been discouraging. He chased the line with his eyes and then with his hands, skirting the capacious talent Gertie’s cappuccino machine had for drama, and found the offender—an outlet frame that had been tightened one corner at a time, seduced into a short by someone who meant well in a century that did not belong to them. He loosened, reseated, tightened in order, soothing the metal with the patience of a man who had learned that speed was a trickster. The lights returned without pomp, and the coffee machine made a noise like gratitude converting itself into crema.

Lionel’s camera had caught the moment they didn’t know to stage: knees on old tile, hands competent without needing to be performed as such, the spontaneous chorus of a room that had not been left in the dark. Later, when Tessa asked him if they could use it as a metaphor, he made a face that was not entirely kind and then nodded because it was also true. He extracted a quiet promise that they would balance it with shots that insisted women’s hands and old tools and the kid at the dish pit also held up the day, and she agreed without giving him a speech about story arcs because she was a person who wanted to be invited to good dinners.

It was not all crisis avoidance and ethical wrangling. There were the small pleasures that make collaboration feel like a picnic instead of a committee—Courtney learning to order a coffee in a blend of French and boldness in St. Boniface and the barista giving her an extra biscuit because she used merci like a kiss; Lionel showing a teenager how to hold a camera without letting it hold him; Yasmin taping a tiny microphone into Gertie’s sleeve with the gentle efficiency of a nurse convinced of your recovery. There was Raj rolling through in a sweater the color of moral persuasion with baked samosas for the crew and a story about a client who had stored heirloom tomatoes in a filing cabinet. There was Mrs. Banerjee pausing on her walk past the Goose to inform the production that their van was parked as if reconsidering the right to be a van, and the piece of equipment was moved without anyone needing to say words like zone or City of Winnipeg in a tone.

They filmed a slice of her forearm and a teaspoon hitting the side of a cup and a bell over the door making a small decision to be charming. They filmed at the rink and used the sound of skates to transition between scenes instead of a jingle, and the editor in Toronto would later call Drew and say, surprised, that ice had rhythm. They filmed Nate at his van, heater wheezing nobly, drawers opened to reveal the OCD of a man whose peace involved labeling, and Tessa laughed out loud and told him to stop apologizing with his eyebrows for being neat. He apologized anyway and then stopped, chastened into practice.

On the last day, weather remembered it had power and brought a thaw that turned intersections into hypotheses. The plan had been to catch the golden hour by the river, camera low, wheat sheaf on his bib from Toronto lent to him again by the Agricultural Society because they believed in second uses. The river, pale and deceptive, sounded like a bar where someone had brought in a musician without telling the regulars. The crew wanted the shot of his city being itself and his feet moving through it in a way that would rhyme with the footage of him in Toronto in his hotel room holding a ribbon like a small absurdity. The ice dared them to be fools. He was not in the mood for foolishness that hurt, only for foolishness that healed, so he led them under the canopy by the market where the wind was banned by consensus and stood there instead, watching people move in bundles and pairs, carrying bread and hockey sticks and the afternoon inside their coats.

“Talk,” Tessa said, softly, as if asking him to tell a story to a kid already asleep but faking it because they wanted more. “Talk about what you would like us to take home from here.”

He could have spoken about the ease of order, about his binding love of strip, twist, cap, about the way a switch that clicks with authority feels like a promise kept. He could have mentioned foxes and napkins and ladders in snack bars, and he almost did. What came out, instead, was something simpler, the way words are simpler when you realize you’re not auditioning for anything.

“I want you to take home the fact that joy happens in dumb places,” he said. “In rinks where dads argue about oatmeal cookies and a breaker decides to be dramatic and someone says no to a staged frost because we already have the weather we need. I want you to know that when people here appear understated it’s sometimes a choice and sometimes it’s the wind. I want you to film our hands and not just our faces. And if someone at a table tells you a story about butter, you need to listen because they are not talking about butter.”

Lionel lowered the camera slightly and then raised it again because cameras are as susceptible to embarrassment as people are. Yasmin shifted her feet on the concrete to warm her toes and nodded just enough to say go on. He did, but only until the words finished, which they did of their own accord, like a good piece of electrical tape running out at exactly the right point on a wrap.

By the time they packed the last cable, the city had turned down its day and put on a coat of evening that made everyone look like a better version of themselves for just long enough to remember they could be. The crew went back to their hotel to argue gently over footage while eating something with a price that could be justified to a boss, and Nate walked to the Goose because he wanted to see if the day had left any crumbs behind. Gertie gave him a slice of pie without ceremony and a look like a confession you never have to pay for. He ate seated on the stool at the end like a man who had decided to be present for his own life and was seeing if it would allow him.

On his way home, his phone buzzed with a text from Moira. It was a picture of a mint on a saucer next to a folded program from a funeral, and her message was a handful of words without fat. Gran went gentle. Peppermint for ballast. He stopped and leaned against a mailbox the color of uncompromising and wrote back what he knew how to say—how her braid had done good work in a room that was too loud and how ladders had been held for him and how he would think of her grandmother when he taught anyone to breathe through a moment that wanted you to do anything but. She wrote a heart, which felt insufficient and perfect, and he put his phone in his pocket.

When he turned the corner onto his street, Mrs. Banerjee was out with the dog, who was wearing a new sweater that declared in block letters I HAVE OPINIONS. She lifted her mitten in salute, and he lifted his chin in return, and it was a rite conducted in the decent light of a day that had offered itself and been accepted. He oil-can’d the van door once for the pleasure of proving to her he had listened and the hinge agreed with him. Upstairs, his kitchen had the quiet of a friend who had done the dishes while you were out and wanted you to notice without making a fuss. On the dresser, the ribbon sat with the voucher, a still life of possible directions.

He made tea in the good mug because he wanted to send himself a message about value. He sat at the table and flipped open his book to where he kept the unglamorous invoices and the glamorous doodles he made during hold music. He drew a ladder and then a pie and then a little cartoon light, and then he wrote at the top of a page: Fixers and Bakers, and underlined it, a cheap ambition made already better by ink. He drew boxes for dates and names, spaces for kids from Raj’s art programs and teens Gertie had inevitably charmed and the boy at the counter who had changed his mind about silly things. He thought about the rink and a lying light and a Saskatchewan fox that had agreed to be seen, about trains and the way time lengthens when you’re kind to it. He thought about Churchill and the north and how his voucher might be a sentence waiting for its verb, and he knew he didn’t have to know yet. He could let that be a window he would open when the air itself asked.

Before bed, he called his mother to tell her that the crew had been kind and that the curtains remained unfed, and she hummed and asked whether the director had worn boots or only thought about boots and whether the world had stopped being impressed by his neat truck. He answered her in enough detail to let her picture his day and not so much that she would worry about the ice. He lay down and felt the city breathe around him, a big lunged animal that was happy to share oxygen. He let sleep arrive the way it arrives when you have not fought it—without bargains, without apology. Outside, on the boulevard, the snow made one last attempt at sparkle and then gave up on theatrics, content to be ordinary under streetlight. In the morning, he would take his ladder to a house with baseboards that dreamed of being younger and he would flip a switch and something would yield to the idea of light, and that would be enough, and when he had time he would build a room where kids could learn how to breathe and to fix and to never be stingy with joy.

Chapter 10

The episode aired on a Thursday that could not decide whether to be winter’s encore or spring’s rehearsal. The day spent itself on indecision—sun that arrived with apology and left with flourish, a wind that tried on three accents before settling on the one that made noses sting. The Blue Goose had announced a watch-along with the matter-of-fact bravado of a place that had survived weddings, wakes, and a brief experiment with gluten-free puff pastry that Gertie insisted had been necessary for science. She taped a handwritten note to the door—TELEVISION TONIGHT, NO JAUNTY MUSIC PERMITTED—and set out bowls of peanuts as if preparing the diner for the weight of a city’s attention.

He finished a job in a house where the baseboards wanted to be younger and the owners wanted dimmers that performed mood without melodrama, and he got to the Goose early because punctuality had revealed itself to him as a form of devotion. The place filled with the slow confidence of regulars plus cousins plus people who had only ever waved in and now found a reason to sit. You could tell the shy from the curious by the way they looked at the TV. The shy looked at the frame. The curious looked at the corners as if to catch the room off guard and thus more honest. Raj arrived with a bag of samosas he had no business calling a contribution and took up a post near the coffee urn as if caffeine required shepherding. Mrs. Banerjee occupied her usual stool with the air of a magistrate conducting an open hearing, the dog at home because crowds turned him into a critic.

The episode began in the modest way TV sometimes remembers to be modest. A train’s window, a snow-bent field, a voiceover that didn’t try to seduce anyone. There was Lionel’s shot of the rink lights finding their courage, and the crowd in the Goose cheered lightly for their own children and then more loudly for their own light, and the sound hit Nate right at the sternum where his better decisions lived. Gertie appeared on screen with earrings like promises and laid out her commandments without committee. In the diner, men who had played hockey with her brother forty years ago slapped the counter and said there she is like a hymn. His mother’s hands came next, the forearm with its good history, the bowl that had been mended and had decided not to be shy about it, and a silence arrived—one you could taste, respectful and hungry—and when her voice broke for one sentence and recovered it, the room breathed together, a lung of people who had been raised by women with aprons and opinions.

He felt the suspense that comes, for only a second, when you are about to see your own face unmediated. He had the impulse to duck behind a pie display and let the room see him in their periphery while he counted bolts of fear. He did not move. He watched himself dodge the camera’s worst habits by standing near a coffee kiosk at ten thirty and doing what he always did, which was to be polite and take exact change and say thank you to something that spent itself on you without expecting praise. He saw his hands on the Goose’s panel when the breaker had done its duty and needed to be told to do it again, and he saw the expression on his own mouth that meant focus and not performance, and he recognized the tilt of his head that had belonged to him since childhood when screws and sorrow had required equal torque.

The show did what it promised—it made room, it did not sneer, it treated the city’s rooms as if they were not backdrops but participants. There was a moment with the warming hut dragged onto land, a pie on a table in the wind, Tessa’s voice absent in favor of the sound the river made promising to get on with it already, and in the Goose there was the particular sniffing sound men make when they will not admit to crying because their eyes have simply chosen this moment to be weather stations. At the end, Lionel’s lens had lingered on a hand on a shoulder—Drew’s, not dramatic, not claiming ownership—just weight shared. The screen went to credits and then to a commercial for insurance that had the gall to make a joke, and the diner finally did what it had been holding in reserve. It erupted, not in a roar but in the sort of chatter that means everyone has been waiting to be generous and now can be. People clapped for each other in the laconic prairie manner that still counts as rapture.

Gertie did not bow, on principle, but she looked at him over the counter and let her smile run without a leash. “Acceptable,” she said, and slid him a slice of pie with no desire to be coy. “No jaunty music.”

“You won,” he said, because accuracy is a kindness.

“We all did, except the man at the network who suggested frost machines,” she replied, and wiped her hands as if that could erase an entire genre of television thoughtlessness. “He will live a long and joyless life, his coffee always slightly wrong.”

People came to his elbow and told him tiny stories about their own trains, about their own lights, about their own hands. A woman from the school board somewhere in the river of conversation said, “We saw the bit at the end where you talked about kids and breathing and ladders. If you need space for a Saturday, we have a gym where the light switches have been pinned back from the eighties and a janitor who will look the other way if he’s invited to judge pie.” She handed him a card that had an actual phone number printed on it and a name underlined with someone’s exasperation. He put it in his pocket in the way you put a spare key in your sock.

He got outside before the compliments turned into a stew he could not digest. The air did him the favor of being honest. Raj followed with the last samosa wrapped in a napkin as if it were a rare bird, and they stood on the sidewalk watching the city do its after-dinner rearrangements. “They loved you,” Raj said, smug on behalf of a plan that had birthed itself into a life. “They loved the forearm more.”

“They should,” he said. “I am still auditioning for my role. The forearm has tenure.”

“You’re starting this thing,” Raj said, blunt because friendship is a hammer when required. “You are going to call it what you wrote down and it will not be a secret from me that you are terrified. I’ve lined up a notary and a woman named Flor who says the words ‘small grant’ the way choir directors say ‘one more time, but with feeling.’ Your job is to show up with screws and breath and the morally correct triangle of strip, twist, cap.”

The first session of Fixers and Bakers did not so much begin as gather around itself, like dough deciding whether or not to rise based on the oven’s attitude. The borrowed gym wore its echoes like a uniform. He and Raj arrived early because tables needed dragging and outlets needed negotiating, and someone had to put masking tape arrows on the floor because children require a geography even when they have no intention of obeying it. Gertie came in backward through the side door carrying two sheet pans that made the hallway smell like sincerity. She had brought hand pies the size of apologies and a stack of paper plates recycled from a church basement. Two high schoolers from Raj’s art program arrived with a box of donated screwdrivers, each tagged with a ribbon as if to prove to the tools that they had been acquired in joy. The Agricultural Society’s man appeared with a thermos that could have heated a church and the amount of apple cider that made people confess.

The kids came the way kids always come—in erratic clumps, carrying grudges and hopes, dragged by aunties or followed by older brothers who would pretend boredom for three entire minutes before wanting a turn. There was the boy from the Goose who had discovered publicly that he could cry at a silly thing, chin forward now like a pilot’s, and there was a girl whose hair made a case for static electricity as a personality trait. A mom with the calm of those who have negotiated with toddlers brought her son who wore soundproof headphones like a crown and whose eyes went to the ladder as if to name it family. He had required waivers printed and signed because the world asked you to avoid drama where possible, and he had fretted about the word being the enemy of joy, but the structure turned out to be a friend. Mrs. Banerjee arrived late, a stack of peppermints in her pocket, and declared herself a safety inspector with an assistant—her dog—whose sweater that day read SMALL BUT PUBLIC.

He began with breath because breath would serve them when everything else jangled. He made them stand with feet ready and hands on their own ribs and he told a story that contained no moral because the point was practice. Then he showed them a switch plate and the insides behind and laid out the words of his lullaby. Strip, twist, cap. He said it twice, soft as bedtime, and the room gave him the gift of quiet. Gertie demonstrated the parallel in dough—cut, crimp, vent—and winked at him as if they had planned it, which they had not, because some things are pre-arranged by the part of the universe in charge of parallels.

They split the kids into groups even though groups made him itchy. It had to be done because otherwise the smallest elbows would find the worst sockets. He took the older ones, the ones with the swagger that required a tool to settle it, and gave them a dead lamp and a box of wire nuts and asked them to bring it back from the border. Raj took the younger ones and taught them how to hold a screwdriver without letting the screwdriver hold them, and he spoke in metaphors that did not apologize for being metaphors. Gertie set the hand pies out with the severity of portion control and then undid all her own rules when a child’s eyes told a more persuasive story about hunger.

There was a moment he had not expected and now would not have traded for a year’s worth of ribbons. A girl with sleeves long enough to hide in had been hovering with that particular studied indifference that hides terror. She held her screwdriver as if it were a snake a magician had made polite. When he came to her table, she did not look up because eyes were traitors, but her hands told a better story. He showed her how to twist with the steadiness that convinces wire it is not being punished, and she followed, and when the two copper ends married under her fingers she made a sound that was not the delighted squeal television asks of girls but a short, grave exhale. He wanted to bow to her competence. He did not. He said, calmly, “You did that,” and she said, as if reporting to an internal tribunal, “Yes.”

They had been going an hour when the gym did the thing buildings do around the ninety-minute mark of children—the lights hiccuped once in solidarity. It was not a crisis, more of a throat clear. The janitor, a man of jokes disguised as frowns, ambled over to the panel and made the gesture people make when they want to help but have learned that touching often makes the situation into more of itself. Nate went with him, because being helpful without owning the room is a skill he was finally proud to have acquired. The breakers were labeled admirably by someone who wrote as if labels prevented chaos in all domains. One was loose in its seat, an old friend he recognized. He reseated it with the pressure that says I mean it and not I dare you, and the room decided to keep being a room.

Nose-smudged cups traveled through the hour, laughter did the honorable labor of making time quick, and the dog, who disliked the echo of gymnasium acoustics on principle, settled under the table with his sweater proclaiming his smallness as a form of protest. Moira appeared on the phone via Raj’s projector like a saint on a stained-glass window, her screen frozen into humor and then resolving. She waved her peppermint at the camera in solemn greeting and taught them an unreasonably useful trick for keeping crust edge from shrinking back on itself, and somewhere in the back the janitor, thinking he was out of range of education, tilted his head and listened as if pie lore were a trade secret he could translate into mopping. Élodie sent a video that played sideways because the universe makes a point of reminding us amateurs are still powerful, and in it she was ankle-deep in slush outside a community center in Rouyn-Noranda, declaring pie club a success because teens had arrived and nobody had set fire to anything except sugar on purpose.

After the cider and the goodbyes and a ritual argument about whether there should be homework—no, unless homework came in the form of breathing—after the janitor had admitted with a gallantry that nearly killed him that the room had not been made worse by this intrusion, after Gertie had tucked three hand pies into a napkin and forced it into the coat of the shy girl “for your mother or for yourself depending on guilt,” after Raj had listed at least six ideas that required both money and a belief in spare hours he did not have, after all that, he stood in the empty gym with a broom, sweeping confetti of wire clippings and paper plate shrapnel into a pile that looked briefly like an emblem of something he could not name. He loved a broom for its honesty. You ask it for order and it gives you little neat hills of evidence.

Outside, late afternoon had flattened into that Winnipeg gray that makes you honest with yourself by removing all flattery. He had two hours until a call from Flor to confirm something about municipal insurance that had the word indemnify in it and made him itch in parts of his body paperwork rarely reached. He took the long way back toward his van because long ways tame adrenaline. Past the park where the snow had worn itself thin and the garbage cans were making unreasonable requests of passersby. Past a garage whose door was open to reveal a man tenderly repainting a bicycle as if it were a shrine. Past the kid’s fort, the pizza-box sign updated for the season—NO DOGS WHO BARK AT FORTS AND NO ADULTS WHO THINK RULES ARE SUGGESTIONS—and he saluted it in his head because he had finally become the adult who did not think rules were suggestions except in cases involving kind shortcuts.

He still needed a space. A place that belonged to the thing, not borrowed in good will and kindly janitorial anxiety. He had been circling a vacancy listing for weeks, a former print shop just off Portage that had been empty long enough to lower its price and its pride. He had talked himself out of it four times and then back in three. Today the version of himself that believed in commitment was in charge. He drove over and parked, looked at the brick with its winter scabs, at the windows that had long ago surrendered to decals promising rush jobs and wedding invitations. The door stuck at the bottom like it had lost faith in coming and going as a model. Inside, the air had the stale optimism of spaces that remember machines. Dust lay on everything with the entitlement of poor landlords.

It was perfect the way damaged things are perfect when they can be repaired. Room enough for tables, a back corner that could be roped off for the ladder and the tools that wanted to be behind a line. An alcove that could hold a secondhand oven if the fire marshal could be seduced by paperwork and proof of adult behavior. He could see the sign above the front window in his mind—FIXERS AND BAKERS—painted without whimsy because the world would supply plenty. He could picture kids arguing about the ethics of pre-slicing electricity. He could hear Gertie bossing a borrowed oven into giving up flake. He could imagine Mrs. Banerjee setting up a folding chair like a bailiff and pronouncing on safety while her dog petitioned for and received a role as morale officer.

The landlord was a man whose cardigan had seen meetings and his eyes had seen late rents without each sighting turning him into a cynic. He walked the space with him with a kind of paternal curiosity. “It was a good print shop,” he said, palm flat on the counter as if feeling the echo of receipts being signed. “Then the world moved that work into computers and into rooms that did not smell like ink. What are you going to put here that will make it smell brave again.”

“Children and sugar,” he said, without thinking he was being clever. “Also, copper and old wood and a little fear managed into usefulness.”

“The city worries about you cutting fingers off the future,” the landlord said, and there it was again, waiver, responsibility, the institutional vocabulary that had chased joy through gymnasiums since the advent of gymnasiums. “We can put things into papers so that everyone has their elbows in.”

“I like elbows in,” he said. “We will put it all into papers and we will put sticky notes on the papers to remind ourselves where we promised to be careful.” He looked at the rent number, felt his stomach do the practical math that had folded him into refusal before, and felt instead, to his surprise, a steadiness. He had the small grant Flor had convinced into being with the authority of someone who treated narratives like budget line items. He had the Agricultural Society’s ongoing mischief. He had a voucher in his desk for a train and he could cash that one way or another into a fundraising story and an event called Pie and Rails in which people would pay to hear Jacques by proxy. He had work that paid his rent and the kind of reputation that meant work would continue. He had a community that had trained him to ask without begging. He put his hand on the counter where paper had once been cut and leaned into the small joy of deciding.

“Okay,” he said, and let the word ring in the room where no words had recently settled. “Okay. We’ll be careful. We’ll be brave but documented. We’ll do it for three months and check if the light flickers.”

The cardigan man smiled and pulled a lease from a folder like a magician aware of his own clichés. They sat on upturned crates because chairs would come later, and the pen he offered was one of those freebies from a tradeshow that wrote more stubbornly if you coaxed. He initialed so many places it became a music. He signed where names ask to be themselves. He thought of the vocabulary of commitment—terms, consideration, delivery—and marveled that his body did not rebel at the words. The landlord shook his hand with the grip of a man whose grandfather had shaken hands even when it snowed, and then left him alone in a space that was now, in the small ways that matter, his.

He paced the perimeter as if a careful dance could turn square footage into something friendlier. He found the light switch and tried it, as you do when you acquire something that claims it can glow. Only two of the fixtures woke, and they did so grudgingly, and he laughed out loud because of course. He fetched his screwdriver because he had brought one without permitting himself to acknowledge that he had brought one, and he popped a lens and did the first repair in a place that would teach repairs. It was small and honest, and when the light steadied it painted the dust into a hundred clear stories.

On his way home he detoured by his mother’s because good news behaved like a dog in him and tugged. She opened the door with a dish towel in her hand because of course she was in the middle of something that smelled like onions and authority. He told her the rent number and the square footage and the fact that he had just agreed to a relationship with a mop. She made a face as if considering him for promotion and nodded once. “I will bring a plant that refuses to die,” she said. “Also, I will bring young onions in a jar because children must learn that cutting something sharp can be safe if you hold it correctly.”

She handed him a jar as if to make good on the promise in advance, and he hugged her because the day had asked him to carry a great deal of brave, and a hug is a form of unloading you do not have to apologize for. On his way out, she leaned out the door as she always did, the evening drafting her voice like an accomplice. “Nathan,” she said, and it was the tone she used when she wanted his attention to be a cathedral. “Teach them to breathe first. Everything else is dessert.”

He slept that night the way he slept when the day had made official some private thought. He dreamed of tables arriving in a truck that had already carried twenty piano recitals and a parade, and a sign being hand-lettered by a boy whose concentration could cut glass, and a landlord’s cardigan draped over a chair after hours because sometimes people forget to take off their roles when they go home. In the morning, the city had iced its sidewalks lightly and then apologized with sun, and he let that be an omen and not a trap. He drove to a job where a woman had called because her porch light overshared its opinion of dusk, and he fixed it with compassion and a little tape and a lot of listening. He took a phone call from Flor while his hands were clean and agreed to a training session on the ethics of youth programs in public spaces because someone had to make sure his good intentions were not going to trip over liability in front of witnesses. He left a message for Moira with the address of the new place and the promise of a chair with her name on it if she ever came west. He texted Élodie a picture of the empty room with the caption: room for a thunderstorm hair guest residency, and she sent back ten lightning bolts and a heart.

By afternoon he was pulling up old vinyl in the shop and discovering beneath it a floor that had made arguments with generations of shoes and would, with persuasion, tell a better story. Raj arrived with a pry bar and enthusiasm and a speech about how he had once installed a gallery show in a room that detested art and had been converted by snacks. They worked until the light called them silly and they kept going anyway, and they talked in the way men talk when their bodies are busy—bits and installments and sudden sincerity like pepper thrown over the shoulder. He told Raj about the moment the shy girl’s hands had believed themselves, and Raj told him about a boy who had brought a sketchbook full of houses into his office and asked where the doors belonged if you wanted people to enjoy leaving and coming back.

When the night finished them rather than the other way around, they sat on the counter in the half-lit room and drank water from mismatched mugs a neighbor had dropped off because the city does that when it senses an opening. In the dark of the window, their faces floated like benevolent signage. “You know what you did,” Raj said, not really asking.

“Signed a lease on a counter I had no legal right to like that much,” he said.

“You put a dome car in a building,” Raj said. “You are going to make a place people can sit in and look up and feel small and safe and in motion, all at once.”

He wanted to protest because the metaphor was too neat and therefore asking for gravity to argue with it. He let it stand because it was also not wrong. He could already hear inside the room the counting of chews at a table, the measured rhythm of twist, the peppermint breath, the laughter when someone admitted the word waiver made their skin itch, the quiet after solutions when people looked at each other with their full faces and not their corners. He could see ladders with hands on them that did not flinch. He could imagine Mrs. Banerjee’s dog in a sweater that read FACILITIES, and he laughed at that, out loud and at length, because joy stored properly does not spoil.

Before he left he took a picture of the room as it was—dust and half-light and the corners where plans collect—and he sent it to his mother and to Gertie and to the Agricultural man and to Moira and Élodie and Ty and to Jacques at the email address Drew had extracted from the ether with polite persistence. He wrote no caption for most and only to Jacques did he add words—room with motion but no wheels yet—and within an hour a reply came in English with vowels round as trains. “Every good car starts with a bench,” Jacques wrote. “Put benches, then you will have passengers. Someone will bleed on a ticket. Keep napkins.”

He went home humming a song he would have been embarrassed to sing, the city obligingly emptying a lane for his van as if it respected the end of a day. In bed, he lay and listened to the building’s pipes tell their stories and thought of the word okay said to empty rooms, train platforms, long tables, and people. He thought of the voucher in the drawer and the north, waiting with foxes. He thought of a Saturday when children would breathe like mechanics and adults would learn where to put their hands when someone else was on the ladder. He let the day pledge itself to tomorrow without being made into a boast. The radiator ticked like a cricket with good manners, and he let sleep come in polite and stay as long as it wanted.
